High-quality afterschool programming during childhood promotes long-term adult mental health
Background
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.
Design, Setting, and Participants
Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.
160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.
Interventions
The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.
Main Outcomes and Measures
Data on the incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions was collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination at a clinic for low-income residents. Although her son's elementary school offers free afterschool programming, her son has not been interested in attending. The son's maternal grandmother has schizophrenia. The mother is inquiring about the benefits of afterschool programming and asks for the physician's input. Based on the study results, which of the following statements best addresses the mother's question?

choices.text: High-quality afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing ADHD risk in adulthood than major depressive disorder risk.
The patient's family history of psychiatric illness prevents conclusions from being drawn from the study.
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with a decreased bipolar disorder risk in adulthood.
High-quality afterschool programming should be free of charge for low-income children to improve adult mental health.
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with decreased ADHD risk in adulthood.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The relative risk for the development of major depressive disorder among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.69, i.e., the investigated intervention produces a 31% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. The risk ratio for the development of ADHD among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.80, which means that the investigated intervention produces a 20% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. This indicates that afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing the risk of depression (31%) than of ADHD (20%).

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient has a strong family history of psychiatric disorder, his family history does not have an effect on the ability to draw conclusions from the study about a population. The abstract notes that the analysis adjusted for family history of income and psychiatric illness, suggesting that the researchers did not draw any conclusions about the effect of family history of mental illness (or interaction between family history and afterschool programming).

C) INCORRECT:

Although at first glance it may appear that children who receive afterschool programming may have a decreased risk of developing bipolar disorder (with a relative risk of 0.64), this finding was not statistically significant because the p-value is 0.34 and the confidence interval includes 1.0. This suggests that the observed difference is likely due to random error.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a policymaker may use the findings of this study to make an argument for increasing access to high-quality afterschool programming, this conclusion cannot be drawn from the study.

E) CORRECT:

The relative risk is a statistical measure used in clinical trials to compare the effect of an intervention on an outcome between two groups over time. A relative risk >1 indicates increased risk, and a relative risk <1 indicates decreased risk in the intervention group compared to the control group. For example, in a clinical trial comparing a new treatment to a placebo, a relative risk of 0.80 for a particular outcome suggests that the risk of experiencing the outcome is 20% (1-0.80) lower in the treatment group compared to the group receiving the placebo.
questions.hint: The abstract describes a randomized, controlled trial (RCT). Results from RCTs only apply to individuals with baseline and clinical characteristics similar to those of the population enrolled in the study and may not be generalizable to other populations. With this in mind, take a look at the relative risk and p-values in the table.

questions.text: A critical care fellow is interested in whether the auscultatory finding of pulmonary rales can accurately predict hypervolemic state. He conducts a study in 100 patients with a volume overloaded state confirmed by a Swan Ganz catheter in his hospital's cardiac critical care unit. He also recruits 100 patients with euvolemic state confirmed by Swan Ganz catheter. He subsequently examines all patients in the unit for rales and finds that 80 patients in the hypervolemic group have rales in comparison to 50 patients in the euvolemic group. Which of the following is the probability that a patient in the study with rales on auscultation truly has hypervolemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

80/100 reflects the sensitivity of the test, i.e. the probability that the test (rales) is positive if the condition (hypervolemia) is present. Sensitivity is calculated as TP/(TP + FN) or TP ÷ all patients with the condition. In this case: sensitivity = 80/(80 + 20) = 80/100 = 80%. Based on this study, 80% of hypervolemic patients will have rales on auscultation.

B) INCORRECT:

50/100 reflects the specificity of the test, i.e. the probability that the test (rales) is negative if the condition (hypervolemia) is absent. The specificity is calculated as TN/(TN + FP) or TN ÷ all patients without the condition. In this case: specificity = 50/(50 + 50) = 50/100 = 50%. Based on this study, there is a 50% chance for euvolemic patients to have rales on auscultation, making this test inappropriate to effectively exclude this condition in euvolemic patients. A test with such a low specificity causes high rates of false positives (e.g., rales due to pneumonia, ARDS).

C) CORRECT:

The PPV is calculated as TP/(TP + FP) or TP ÷ all patients who tested positive. In this case PPV = 80/(80 + 50) = 80/130 ≈ 62%. Based on this study, the PPV suggests that if an individual in the study has rales on auscultation, the likelihood of that patient truly being in a hypervolemic state is approx. 62%.

It is important to note that PPV and negative predictive value (NPV) are posttest probabilities (PoTPs), which are dependent on the condition's prevalence (i.e., pretest probability). In order to calculate the true PoTPs, the condition's prevalence in the sample population must be identical to its value in the general population in consideration but this might not be feasible in all study designs. This study's PoTPs will not have external validity because the researcher selected 100 patients with hypervolemia and 100 with euvolemia for the sample population. In such a situation, the researcher can use test characteristics (sensitivity and specificity), which are independent of prevalence, and the true prevalence (obtained from medical literature) to calculate the true PoTPs.

D) INCORRECT:

50/70 reflects the negative predictive value (NPV), i.e. the likelihood that a patient with a negative test result (no rales) truly does not have the disease (i.e., is euvolemic). NPV is calculated as TN/(TN + FN) or TN ÷ all patients who tested negative. In this case: NPV = 50/(50 + 20) = 50/70 ≈ 71.4%. Based on this study, if a patient does not have rales on auscultation, the likelihood of being in a euvolemic state is approx. 71.4%.

E) INCORRECT:

100/200 is the prevalence of cases with hypervolemia in the sample population of 200 patients. The prevalence is calculated as the number of people with a condition/the total number of people studied. In this case, prevalence = 100/200 = 50%. Accordingly, 50% of the study population is in a state of hypervolemia. Note that this is not the true prevalence of hypervolemia in the cardiac critical care unit.
questions.hint: It may help to create a two-by-two table with the values mentioned in the stem and then calculate the number of true positives (TP), true negatives (TN), false positives (FP), and false negatives (FN). The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that a patient with a positive test result (i.e., presence of rales on auscultation) truly has the condition (i.e., hypervolemia).

Predictors of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in HIV-positive adults
Background:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive cancer commonly seen in HIV-positive patients. It is also the most common aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the United States. Given that the risk profile for DLBCL remains unclear, this study seeks to identify predictors of DLBCL.
Methods:
Data was obtained via retrospective chart review at a major tertiary academic medical center in California in 2017. A total of 9,820 adults with HIV diagnoses between 2000 and 2002 and subsequently started on combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) were identified. Data on demographics and antiretroviral regimen were obtained. The prevalence of DLBCL cases in the cohort, as of 2017, was obtained via chart review. Medication adherence was assessed by analyzing pharmacy claims linked to patient charts and calculating a Medication Possession Rate (MPR), the total amount of time a medication was dispensed to patients divided by treatment period. Patients with a past or present history of cancer preceding HIV diagnosis, as well as missing data on key variables, were excluded from analysis.

A 63-year-old HIV-positive man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and was started on cART therapy. He tells the physician that he has been having difficulty adhering to his medication regimen. He has been unemployed for the past couple of years and relies on unemployment benefits to cover the costs of daily living. His father died of lymphoma at the age of 60 years. He had recently heard about the results of the study featured in the abstract and wants more information about his risk of developing DLBCL. Based on the study, which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a similar profile as this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a positive family history in comparison to patients without a family history of cancer is 1.35, suggesting a 35% increased risk of developing DLBCL in patients with a positive family history. However, the p-value of 0.08 is higher than the conventional p-value cutoff point of 0.05, and the confidence interval of 0.93–1.43 includes 1.0, indicating that there is no statistically significant difference in DLBCL risk based on family history of cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in male patients in comparison to female patients is 1.08. This suggests an 8% increased risk of developing DLBCL in male patients compared to female patients. Although this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.02), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

C) CORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with high adherence to cART in comparison to patients with low adherence to cART is 0.69. From this, you can calculate a 31% decreased risk of DLBCL in patients with high adherence to cART compared to patients with low adherence to cART. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among low adherence patients compared to high adherence patients would be 1/0.69 ≈ 1.45, corresponding to a 45% increased risk. The p-value for this relative risk is 0.03, meaning there is a statistically significant relationship between cART adherence and development of DLBCL.

D) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL among HIV-positive patients with an annual income between $30,000 and $90,000 and above $90,000 compared to below $30,000 is 0.87 and 0.88, respectively, indicating a decreased risk. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among patients with a yearly income below $30,000 (compared to between $30,000 and $90,000) is 1/0.87 ≅ 1.15, corresponding to a 15% increased risk. Though this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.04), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

E) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients ≥ 55 years of age compared to patients < 55 years is 1.21, with a p-value of 0.11, indicating that there is no statistically significant increased risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients 55 years or older compared to patients younger than 55.
questions.hint: The abstract describes a retrospective cohort study. As a measure of the probability that observed results occurred by chance, p-values help determine the statistical significance of a relationship between two variables (e.g., a p-value of 0.05 indicates the probability of seeing the observed results by chance is 5%, assuming the null hypothesis is true). The magnitude of relative risk (not the p-value), however, is a measure of how strongly a risk factor is associated with a given outcome.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is analyzing data in a nationwide cancer registry. She identified a group of patients who had recently undergone surgery for epithelial ovarian cancer and achieved a complete clinical response to chemotherapy. Some of these patients had been scheduled to receive annual abdominal CTs while other patients had not been scheduled for such routine imaging surveillance. The medical student then identified a subgroup of patients who have developed recurrent metastatic disease despite their previous complete clinical response to chemotherapy and surgery. She compared patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer during routine follow-up imaging with patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer based on clinical symptoms at routine follow-up history and physical exams. She found that the average survival of patients who underwent routine imaging was four months longer than the survival of their peers who were diagnosed based on history and physical exam. Which of the following would most likely be found in this study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observer bias is a type of bias that occurs when knowledge or expectations of the individuals collecting the data affects the investigation, e.g., if the researcher's knowledge of the patients' exposure statuses influenced the classification of patients as cases or noncases. There is nothing here to suggest that the diagnosis of metastatic cancer by the radiologists or other physicians was influenced by factors other than objective evidence of disease on screening or at presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Lead time is the time between the detection of a disease through screening and its clinical presentation. Lead-time bias results from deducing a longer survival from earlier disease detection while disregarding the time from detection to disease onset. In other words, survival may appear longer if measured from the time of diagnosis to the time of death, even though it remains the same if measured from the time of disease onset to the time of death. Lead-time bias can be overcome by measuring the back-end survival, i.e., adjusting the survival according to the severity of the disease at the time of diagnosis.

See “Potential sources of bias in screening tests” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Confounding bias is a type of bias in which an association is assumed to exist between an exposure and outcome when, in fact, a third variable (the confounder) that was not included in the study is associated with both the exposure and the outcome. There is no information contained in the question stem that suggests the apparent relationship between screening for metastatic cancer and survival is distorted by a third variable.

D) INCORRECT:

Information bias can occur if information is gathered differently between the treatment and control group. Information bias may occur if the sample group of participants screened for metastatic epithelial ovarian cancer were a mix of patients screened with ultrasound and CT, or if the calculator used to count the number of patients screened with ultrasound or CT were broken. There is no evidence of such error in measurement based on the information provided in the question stem.

E) INCORRECT:

There is generally a longer period of time between disease onset and clinical manifestation in patients with slowly progressing disease compared to those with rapid disease progression. Therefore, the opportunity for detecting disease is greater in cases where the disease progress more slowly. Subsequently, a disproportionately high number of slowly progressing diseases are detected through screening, which is known as length-time bias. This may create a false impression that a screening test improves outcome or prognosis. A classic example is a cancer screening test that is assumed to improve survival rate but actually detects a higher number of asymptomatic, slow-growing tumors, i.e., the calculated survival rate is higher than the actual survival rate due to disproportionally more study participants with less aggressive disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Surveillance bias is a type of bias in which a disease is diagnosed more frequently in a sample population than in the general population due to the increased testing and monitoring within that sample. In this case, recurrent ovarian cancer was detected earlier in the group that underwent close surveillance with imaging. However, while this may have influenced the calculation of survival times, it did not skew the outcome of this study itself.
questions.hint: Survival in patients with metastatic epithelial ovarian cancer may appear longer if measured from the time of diagnosis to the time of death even though survival may remain the same if measured from the onset of disease to the time of death.

questions.text: A new assay for Lyme disease has been developed. While the assay has been tested extensively in Maine, a group of investigators is planning to test it in Southern California. In comparison to the assay's performance in Maine, testing the assay in Southern California would affect the performance of the assay in which of the following ways?

choices.text: Decreased negative likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
Lower likelihood that a patient without Lyme disease truly has a negative test
Greater likelihood that an individual with a positive test will truly have Lyme disease
Decreased positive likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
Lower likelihood that a patient with Lyme disease will truly have a positive test
Greater likelihood that an individual with a negative test will truly not have Lyme disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The negative likelihood ratio is calculated from the sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are not affected by disease prevalence. Therefore, the negative likelihood ratio of the assay will not change when it is tested in Southern California instead of Maine.

B) INCORRECT:

The likelihood that a patient without the disease will have a negative test result is the specificity. Specificity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by disease prevalence.

C) INCORRECT:

The likelihood that an individual with a positive test truly does have the disease is the PPV. The PPV increases when a diagnostic test is used in a population with a higher prevalence of disease (i.e., the disease is more common), but in this case, the assay was tested in a population with a lower prevalence of disease (Southern California) compared to the first population in which it was tested (Maine). Consequently, the PPV of the assay will be lower in Southern California than in Maine (i.e., the likelihood of true positives will decrease).

D) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated from the sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are not affected by disease prevalence. Therefore, the positive likelihood ratio of the assay will not change when it is tested in Southern California instead of Maine.

E) INCORRECT:

The likelihood that a patient with a disease will have a positive test result is the sensitivity. Sensitivity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by disease prevalence.

F) CORRECT:

The likelihood that an individual with a negative test result truly does not have the disease (i.e., that it is a true negative) is the NPV. The NPV is inversely related to prevalence; NPV increases as disease prevalence decreases. In this case, performing the assay for Lyme disease in Southern California (low prevalence) instead of in Maine (high prevalence) will result in an increased NPV (i.e., the likelihood of true negatives will increase). PPV is directly related to prevalence; PPV decreases as disease prevalence decreases.

Prevalence does not influence intrinsic test characteristics, i.e. sensitivity, specificity, negative likelihood ratio, and positive likelihood ratio.
questions.hint: Lyme disease primarily occurs in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US; its prevalence is much lower in Southern California than in Maine. Prevalence (pretest probability) affects posttest probabilities, i.e., negative predictive value (NPV) and positive predictive value (PPV).

questions.text: An inpatient psychiatrist recently had two patients who developed serious gastrointestinal infections while taking clozapine. He was concerned that his patients had developed agranulocytosis, a relatively rare but dangerous adverse event associated with clozapine. When the psychiatrist checked the absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of both patients, one was 450/mm3, while the other was 700/mm3 (N = 1500/mm3). According to the clozapine REMS (Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy) program, severe neutropenia in clozapine recipients has often been defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 500/mm3. Changing the cutoff value to 750/mm3 would affect the test performance of ANC with regard to agranulocytosis in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 decreases the number of true negatives (i.e., individuals without agranulocytosis who correctly test negative).

B) INCORRECT:

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 results in a decreased positive predictive value (PPV), as PPV = True Positives/(True Positives + False Positives). PPV decreases because the number of false positives increases more than the number of true positives.

Raising the cutoff value increases the negative predictive value (NPV), as NPV = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Negatives). NPV increases because the number of false negatives decreases more than the number of true negatives.

C) INCORRECT:

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 increases the number of true positives (i.e., individuals with agranulocytosis who correctly test positive).

D) INCORRECT:

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 decreases the specificity of the test, so fewer individuals who truly do not have agranulocytosis (true negatives) are correctly identified as negative.

E) CORRECT:

The effect of changing a cutoff value depends on whether the test requires a high cutoff value (e.g., tumor marker for cancer, lipase for pancreatitis) or a low cutoff value for diagnosis (e.g., this test for agranulocytosis). For this test, raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 broadens the inclusion criteria for agranulocytosis, increasing the rate of true and false positives while decreasing the rate of true and false negatives. Broadening the inclusion criteria in this test also increases sensitivity and decreases specificity. In addition, broadening inclusion criteria in a low cutoff value test decreases the test's positive predictive value while increasing its negative predictive value.

Be aware: In tests for which a high cutoff value is diagnostic, raising the cutoff value increases specificity and decreases sensitivity. By contrast, in agranulocytosis, a low cutoff value is diagnostic; therefore, raising the cutoff has the opposite effect.

F) INCORRECT:

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 increases the sensitivity of the test because it decreases the number of false negatives. The true positives increase, but because the false negatives decrease, the denominator increases by less than the numerator, increasing the result of the formula for sensitivity: True Positives/(True Positives + False Negatives). As a result, more individuals who truly have agranulocytosis (true positives) are identified as having the condition.
questions.hint: Keep in mind that this is a test in which a low cutoff value is diagnostic. Raising the cutoff from 500/mm3 to 750/mm3 broadens the inclusion criteria, meaning that more patients who truly have agranulocytosis test positive. However, broadening the criteria for agranulocytosis has a disadvantage.

questions.text:
A cohort study was conducted to investigate the impact of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) on asthma symptoms in a group of firefighters who worked at Ground Zero during the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City and developed asthma in the attack's aftermath. The study compared patients who had PTSD with those who did not have PTSD in order to determine if PTSD is associated with worse asthma control. During a follow-up period of 12 months, the researchers found that patients with PTSD had a greater number of hospitalizations for asthma exacerbations (RR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval = 1.4–2.5) after adjusting for medical comorbidities, psychiatric comorbidities other than PTSD, and sociodemographic variables. Results are shown:

Based on these results, what proportion of asthma hospitalizations in patients with PTSD could be attributed to PTSD?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

2.0 is the relative risk (RR), i.e., the risk of a patient with PTSD requiring hospitalization for asthma exacerbations compared to the risk of requiring hospitalization for asthma exacerbations without PTSD. The RR can be calculated by dividing the incidence of asthma exacerbations in PTSD patients by the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD: (80/160)/(50/200) = 0.5/0.25 = 2. A relative risk > 1.0 indicates a positive association and increased likelihood of asthma exacerbations in patients with PTSD. However, the RR does not measure the magnitude of the excess risk attributable to PTSD. To estimate the proportion of asthma hospitalizations attributable to PTSD in patients with PTSD, the ARP needs to be calculated.

B) INCORRECT:

0.25 is the AR, i.e., the difference between the risk of asthma exacerbation in the PTSD group and the group of patients without PTSD. The AR is calculated by taking the absolute risk of PTSD patients and subtracting the absolute risk of patients without PTSD. In this case, (80/160) - (50/200) = (0.5 - 0.25) = 0.25 or 25%. This means that patients in the PTSD group have an excess risk of 25% of developing an asthma exacerbation compared to patients in the group without PTSD.

C) INCORRECT:

3.0 is the odds ratio (OR), i.e., the probability of PTSD in a patient with an asthma exacerbation that requires hospitalization. The OR can be calculated as the odds of disease in the exposed group divided by the odds of disease in the unexposed group. In this case: OR = (80/80)/(50/150) = 1/(1/3) = 3. An OR > 1 means that there is an increased odds of patients with asthma exacerbation having PTSD.

D) CORRECT:

The proportion of asthma hospitalizations attributable to PTSD in the PTSD group is the ARP, which can be calculated based on the RR: ARP = (RR - 1)/RR. The RR can be calculated by dividing the incidence of asthma exacerbations in PTSD patients by the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD: (80/160)/(50/200) = 0.5/0.25 = 2. In this case, ARP = (2.0 - 1)/2.0 = 0.50. This means that 50% of the asthma exacerbations in the PTSD group can be attributed to PTSD.

Alternatively, the ARP can be calculated from the 2x2 table: ARP = attributable risk/risk in the exposed group. In this case, the risk in the exposed group is 80/160 = 0.5 and the AR = (80/160) - (50/200) = (0.5 - 0.25) = 0.25. Consequently, ARP = 0.25/0.5 = 0.50 or 50%.

E) INCORRECT:

4.0 is the number needed to harm (NNH), i.e., the number of individuals who need to be exposed (in this case, meaning the presence of PTSD) before one person develops an asthma exacerbation. NNH is calculated as: 1/attributable risk (AR). To determine the attributable risk here, the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients with PTSD is subtracted from the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD. In this case, NNH is: 1/((80/160) - (50/200)) = 1/(0.5 - 0.25) = 1/0.25 = 4. In other words, 4 people need to develop PTSD in order to cause an asthma exacerbation in 1 patient.
questions.hint: This question asks for the attributable risk percent (ARP) i.e., the proportion of excess risk in the exposed group attributable to the exposure. Attributable risk (AR), in contrast, measures the absolute risk difference between the exposed and unexposed groups. You can calculate ARP using the 2x2 table or the relative risk (RR).

questions.text: A patient with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and a long history of alcohol use disorder and chronic hepatitis C has been using the mTOR inhibitor metalimus 100 mg for cancer treatment. Her cancer has shown a partial response. She also has a history of hypertension and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic retinopathy. Current medications include enalapril and insulin. She asks her oncologist and hepatologist if she could try Noxbinle (tumorolimus) for its purported survival benefit in treating HCC. Based on the data provided in the drug advertisement, which of the following responses is most accurate?

choices.text: "You are not a good candidate for Noxbinle because of your history of hypertension."
"Your history of diabetes may disqualify you from taking Noxbinle."
"You should start Noxbinle 50 mg because it has a survival benefit relative to your current medication."
"You should start Noxbinle 100 mg because it has a survival benefit relative to your current medication."
"You should start taking Noxbinle 50 mg because your history of alcohol use disorder and hepatitis C disqualifies you from taking a higher dosage."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The only statistically significant difference in adverse events between Noxbinle and Metalimus were seen in nephrotoxicity, impaired wound healing, hyperglycemia, and new infections (page 2). The advertisement does not report any cardiovascular adverse events. Consequently, the patient's history of hypertension is not a contraindication to Noxbinle.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a partial response to Metalimus without any reported side effects. The adverse events profile of Noxbinle on page 2 shows that almost 60% of patients receiving Noxbinle 100 mg develop hyperglycemia. Given this patient's history of poorly controlled diabetes, she may not be a good candidate for Noxbinle 100 mg. Although this difference in risk is only statistically significant for the 100 mg dosage, the advertisement also states that there is no survival benefit for lower dosages (page 1). Consequently, she should not receive Noxbinle 25 mg or 50 mg either.

C) INCORRECT:

The Kaplan-Meier survival plots on page 1 show a survival benefit for Noxbinle relative to Metalimus specifically for the 100 mg dosage. The advertisement states that there is no survival benefit for lower dosages relative to Metalimus 100 mg.

D) INCORRECT:

Although there is a survival benefit for patients who received Noxbinle 100 mg relative to Metalimus 100 mg, Noxbinle 100 mg is associated with a risk of serious adverse events that could affect this patient. Given the patient's medical history, she should not receive Noxbinle 100 mg due to safety concerns.

E) INCORRECT:

As the Kaplan-Meier survival plots on page 1 show, there was a survival benefit for Noxbinle 100 mg relative to Metalimus 100 mg, but there was no survival benefit for lower Noxbinle dosages relative to Metalimus.
questions.hint: Note the adverse events associated with Noxbinle as well as the dose that has been demonstrated to show a survival benefit relative to Metalimus.

questions.text: A hepatologist has learned about the survival benefit of Noxbinle (tumorolimus) in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients from a fellow physician. She is looking at a list of HCC patients on her hospital's hepatology consult service and trying to identify candidates who might derive more survival benefits from Noxbinle as opposed to Metalimus. Based on the information provided in the drug advertisement, which of the following patients with HCC would be an appropriate treatment candidate and benefit the most from treatment with Noxbinle 100 mg in comparison to Metalimus 100 mg?

choices.text: Patient without cirrhosis with a history of hepatitis B and alcohol use disorder
Patient with severe cirrhosis and a history of alcohol use disorder who is on immunosuppressive therapy
Patient with severe cirrhosis, history of hepatitis C, and kidney stones
Patient with severe cirrhosis, history of hepatitis C, and asthma
Patient with moderate cirrhosis, a history of alcohol use disorder, and nausea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The table on page 1 shows that Noxbinle 100 mg does not have a survival benefit in patients without a history of cirrhosis compared to Metalimus 100 mg (HR = 0.86, p = 0.21). The table shows that patients with and without a history of alcohol use disorder benefit from Noxbinle 100 mg (HR = 0.77, p < 0.01 compared to HR = 0.73, p = 0.01). Furthermore, patients with and without a hepatitis B infection benefit from treatment. However, another condition is associated with an even higher survival benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

The table on page 1 shows that Noxbinle 100 mg does indeed have an increased survival benefit in patients with severe cirrhosis (HR = 0.61, p < 0.01) in comparison to patients taking Metalimus 100 mg. However, the adverse events figure on page 2 illustrates that new infections are a significant side effect attributable to Noxbinle 100 mg, which makes this medication less desirable in a patient on immunosuppressive therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

The table on page 1 shows that Noxbinle 100 mg indeed has an increased survival benefit in patients with severe cirrhosis (HR = 0.61, p < 0.01) compared to Metalimus 100 mg. However, the adverse events figure on page 2 shows that nephrotoxicity, which encompasses renal calculi, is a significant side effect of Noxbinle 100 mg, which makes this medication less desirable in a patient with preexisting kidney stones.

D) CORRECT:

The table on page 1 shows that patients with severe cirrhosis who take Noxbinle 100 mg have an increased survival benefit (HR = 0.61, p < 0.01) compared to patients taking Metalimus 100 mg. The fact that this patient has hepatitis C matters less than a history of severe cirrhosis with regard to survival benefit from Noxbinle 100 mg, as patients with and without a history of viral hepatitis both appear to benefit from Noxbinle 100 mg (HR = 0.78, p = 0.01; HR = 0.81, p = 0.02, respectively). In addition, there is no evidence presented in the drug advertisement that a history of asthma is a contraindication for Noxbinle 100 mg; there is no significant difference shown in the risk of dyspnea or cough in patients taking Metalimus 100 mg and Noxbinle 100 mg in the adverse events figure on page 2.

E) INCORRECT:

The table on page 1 shows that Noxbinle 100 mg would not result in an increased survival outcome in a patient with a history of alcohol use disorder because both patients with such history (HR = 0.77, p < 0.01) and patients without such history (HR = 0.73, p = 0.01) appear to benefit from the medication. While Noxbinle 100 mg does indeed have a survival benefit in patients with moderate cirrhosis compared to Metalimus 100 mg (HR = 0.82, p = 0.03), another condition is associated with an even higher survival benefit. In addition, nausea does not occur statistically significantly more often in patients taking Noxbinle 100 mg than in patients taking Metalimus 100 mg, so the patient's nausea would not be a contraindication.
questions.hint: It is critical to consider which patients derive the most survival benefits from Noxbinle (see table on page 1) and which conditions are predisposing factors for Noxbinle's side effects (see figure on page 2).

questions.text: A physician is evaluating the efficacy of Noxbinle in preventing death due to HCC at the population level. He examines the survival data featured in the Noxbinle advertisement and wants to estimate how likely it is that Noxbinle will help an individual patient with HCC. Based on the table provided in the drug advertisement, how many patients need to be treated with Noxbinle 100 mg, rather than Metalimus 100 mg, to prevent, on average, one death from HCC after 2 years of treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The hazard ratio (HR) for death in the advertised study was 0.73. HRs are a measurement of how often a particular event (death) occurs in one group (treatment with Noxbinle 100 mg) compared to how often it occurs in another group (e.g., treatment with Metalimus), over time. In this case, a hazard ratio of 0.73 implies that at any time point during the study, patients treated with Noxbinle 100 mg were 27% less likely to die than patients treated with Metalimus. This is not equivalent to the NNT.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the difference in the absolute number of deaths between the treatment group (Noxbinle 100 mg) and the control group (Metalimus 100 mg): 450 - 400 = 50. This is not equivalent to the NNT.

C) INCORRECT:

20% (100/500) is the proportion of patients who were still alive in the treatment group (Noxbinle 100 mg) at the end of the study period. This is not equivalent to the NNT.

D) INCORRECT:

100 is the number of patients still alive in the treatment group (Noxbinle 100 mg) at the end of the study. This is not equivalent to the NNT.

E) CORRECT:

Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in risk (risk of death) attributable to exposure (Noxbinle) as compared to nonexposure (Metalimus): ARR = risk in nonexposed (control) group – risk in exposed (treatment) group. The table on page 1 shows that after 2 years, 50 out of 500 patients were still alive in the control group (i.e., 450 had died) compared to 100 out of 500 patients in the treatment group (i.e., 400 had died). The risk of death is 450/500 = 0.9 for the control group and 400/500 = 0.8 for the treatment group. In conclusion, the ARR = 0.9 – 0.8 = 0.1. The NNT is the inverse of the ARR: NNT = 1/ARR; therefore, NNT = 1/0.1 = 10. On average, ten patients must be treated with Noxbinle 100 mg instead of Metalimus 100 mg to prevent one additional death from hepatocellular carcinoma after 2 years of treatment.
questions.hint: The table on page 1 summarizes the risk of death for the treatment group (Noxbinle 100 mg) and the control group (Metalimus 100 mg). The value to look for is the number needed to treat (NNT), which can be calculated as the inverse of absolute risk reduction (NNT = 1/ARR).

questions.text: The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) is a commonly used nine-question diagnostic test for major depression. A medical student is collecting data on the test's sensitivity and specificity to validate the PHQ-9 questionnaire for his summer project. The student plots the data, forming the green line in the figure. A total score of 20 out of 27 on the PHQ-9 questionnaire, which is generally used as a cutoff for a high likelihood of severe depression, is represented by point A on the graph. If the PHQ-9 questionnaire were administered in such a way that a score of 15 out of 27 was diagnostic instead, which of the points on the graph would most accurately represent the new PHQ-9 cutoff?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Changing the cutoff value from 20 to 15 out of 27 points affects the sensitivity and specificity of the PHQ-9 questionnaire and, thus, the position of the cutoff on the ROC curve as well.

B) CORRECT:

Point B on the ROC curve represents the new cutoff point for severe depression. In ROC curves, the y-axis represents the sensitivity (true positive rate) and the x-axis corresponds to 1 - specificity (false positive rate). By lowering the cutoff from 20 to 15 out of 27 points, more people will be diagnosed as severely depressed. Thus, the sensitivity of the PHQ-9 test slightly increases (more true positives). At the same time, however, the specificity will decrease (more false positives).

Ideally, the cutoff point is on a curve in the upper left corner, where sensitivity and specificity are 100% (the highest rate of true positives together with the lowest rate of false positives).
Image Description:

The ROC curve illustrates the relationship between the sensitivity and specificity of a test.

The more closely the curve follows the Y axis, the more accurate the test. The more close the curve is to the diagonal dotted line (x = y), the less accurate the test.

When choosing a cutoff value, an upward shift on the ROC curve indicates increased sensitivity, and a shift to the right indicates decreased specificity.

C) INCORRECT:

This would represent an increased cutoff value (e.g., a total score of 25 out of 27 as diagnostic cutoff instead of a total score of 20 out of 27) on the PHQ-9 questionnaire. An increased cutoff value would go hand in hand with an increased specificity (more true negatives and fewer false positives) but decreased sensitivity (fewer true positives).

D) INCORRECT:

Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).

E) INCORRECT:

Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).

F) INCORRECT:

Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).

G) INCORRECT:

A curve close to or on the diagonal line (line of no-discrimination) indicates a nondiagnostic or useless study. On this line, sensitivity equals 1 - specificity and the positive likelihood ratio equals 1. This means that the test in question is no more diagnostic than chance (i.e., a test that yields positive or negative results entirely unrelated to the true disease status). Changing the cutoff of the questionnaire would not render the test useless.
questions.hint: Every diagnostic test involves a trade-off between sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity is increased at the expense of specificity when the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire is lowered.

questions.text: To conduct a case-control study, an endocrine surgeon selects patients who experienced a hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection and patients who did not experience this complication during pheochromocytoma surgery. She then compares the two groups with regard to the number of patients with underlying MEN 2 syndromes. The surgeon subsequently calculates an odds ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), indicating that patients who experienced intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal are 3.4 times more likely to have underlying MEN 2 syndromes than patients in the control group. In her publication, the surgeon reports a risk ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), concluding that the risk for patients with MEN 2 syndromes developing intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is 3.4 times greater than for patients without MEN 2 syndromes. Considering the study design, which of the following concepts is the most important prerequisite to allow the surgeon to come to this conclusion?

choices.text: Prevalence of MEN type 2 syndromes is low
Hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection is rare
The case-control study used a large sample size
The relationship between MEN 2 syndromes and intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is not due to random error
Pheochromocytoma is common in MEN 2 syndromes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the prevalence of MEN 2 syndromes is low, the values representing the exposure in a standard contingency table, a and b, become very small. In this case, the odds ratio indicates an association between exposure and outcome without providing an estimate of the relative risk.

B) CORRECT:

The rare disease assumption is the most important prerequisite that allows for this surgeon's conclusion. This concept assumes that if the incidence of a study's outcome (in this case, hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection) is low (i.e., the disease is rare), the odds ratio approximates the relative risk. Usually, the relative risk cannot be established in case-control studies because subjects are not tracked over time. Instead, the odds ratio is calculated to determine whether there is an association between an exposure and outcome (in this case, MEN 2 syndrome and intraoperative hypertension, respectively), although the OR does not provide a quantitative estimate of the risk. Because intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma resection is rare, the rare disease assumption holds that OR is approximately equal to RR. It can thus be assumed that the risk of intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is 3.4 times greater in patients with MEN 2 syndromes than in patients without MEN 2 syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

The size of the case-control study does not determine whether the relative risk can be estimated from the odds ratio or not. The odds ratio approximates the relative risk only in one specific circumstance.

D) INCORRECT:

A p-value < 0.05 (here p < 0.01) indicates that the association between MEN 2 syndromes and intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is statistically significant rather than due to chance or random error. However, this does not allow us to assume that the relative risk is equal to the odds ratio here.

E) INCORRECT:

While pheochromocytoma is common in individuals with MEN 2 syndromes, occurring in approx. 50% of patients, this has no bearing on the assumption that the odds ratio approximates the relative risk.
questions.hint: In a standard contingency table, the odds ratio is calculated as OR = (a/c)/(b/d) = (a/b)/(c/d), while the relative risk is calculated as RR = (a/(a + b))/(c/(c + d)). Normally, RR cannot be calculated from case-control studies. However, when the values representing the diseased population, a and c, become insignificant compared to the values representing the nondiseased population, b and d, RR approximates the OR: RR ≈ (a/b)/(c/d).

questions.text:
A hematologist has found a historical hemocytometer used during the 1960s. Out of curiosity, he decides to obtain platelet counts from his brother, who has immune thrombocytopenic purpura, with both the historical hemocytometer and a modern automated CBC analyzer. The platelet counts of repeated measurements are shown in ascending order:


Historical hemocytometer
55,000
57,000
62,000
76,000
77,000
82,000
92,000
Mean: 72,000


Modern automated CBC analyzer
71,000
71,000
72,000
72,000
73,000
74,000
74,000
Mean: 72,000


If the measurements on a modern automated CBC analyzer are considered accurate, which of the following conclusions can be drawn about the historical hemocytometer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (platelet counts). A lack of accuracy would probably have resulted in a different mean compared to the modern automated CBC analyzer.

B) INCORRECT:

Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura). A lack of validity would have resulted in a different mean than the modern automated CBC analyzer.

C) INCORRECT:

Specificity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have a certain disease (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura; ITP). As there are no standard values for normal or ITP-altered platelet counts offered here, no conclusions about specificity can be drawn.

D) CORRECT:

Based on the results presented, the historical hemocytometer lacks precision (reliability). The test is unreliable, as it does not consistently give similar results on repeated measurements. The range (statistics) of results of the historical hemocytometer is 55,000–92,000, while the range of results of the modern automated CBC analyzer is much smaller (71,000–74,000), indicating that it is more precise. Random errors result in single values differing significantly from the mean during test-retest measurement, which reduces the precision of a test.
Image Description:

Illustration of the principles of reliability (precision) and validity (accuracy)

The crosses represent data points from repeated measurements taken using the same instrument, and the target represents the true value of the attribute being measured.

Reliability refers to how similar the data points are to each other: when reliability is low, the data points are more widely dispersed. When reliability is high, the data points are more close together.

Validity refers to how close the data points are to the true value: when validity is low, the data points do not approximate the true value.

E) INCORRECT:

Sensitivity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who have a certain disease (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura; ITP). As there are no standard values for normal or ITP-altered platelet count values offered here, no conclusions about sensitivity can be drawn.
questions.hint: While the mean of the two sets of measurements is the same, the measures of dispersion (e.g., range) are higher with the historical hemocytometer.

questions.text: A physician at an internal medicine ward notices that several of his patients have hyponatremia without any associated symptoms. Severe hyponatremia, often defined as < 120 mEq/L, is associated with altered mental status, coma, and seizures, and warrants treatment with hypertonic saline. Because some patients are chronically hyponatremic, with serum levels < 120 mEq/L, but remain asymptomatic, the physician is considering decreasing the cutoff value for severe hyponatremia to < 115 mEq/L. Changing the cutoff value to < 115 mEq/L would affect the validity of serum sodium in predicting severe hyponatremia in which of the following ways?

choices.text: Increased specificity and decreased negative predictive value
Decreased specificity and increased negative predictive value
Decreased sensitivity and increased negative predictive value
Increased sensitivity and decreased positive predictive value
Decreased sensitivity and decreased positive predictive value
Increased specificity and decreased positive predictive value

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Be aware: The effect of lowering a cutoff value depends on whether the test has a high or low original cutoff. In diagnostic tests with a high cutoff value (e.g., CA 125 for ovarian cancer, lipase for pancreatitis), lowering the cutoff broadens the inclusion criteria and therefore increases sensitivity and negative predictive value (NPV) while decreasing specificity and positive predictive value (PPV). In diagnostic tests with a low cutoff value, lowering the cutoff has the opposite effect, decreasing sensitivity and NPV while increasing specificity and PPV.

Because this test for severe hyponatremia already has a low cutoff value, lowering the cutoff further narrows the inclusion criteria and decreases the number of positive results while increasing the number of negative results. Lowering the cutoff therefore decreases the false positives (FP) and true positives (TP) and increases the true negatives (TN) and false negatives (FN).

Specificity = TN/(TN + FP). Because TN increase and FP decrease, the numerator increases by more than the denominator, and the result (value of the fraction) increases. Therefore, lowering the cutoff value in a test that already has a low cutoff increases specificity, making it more likely that a patient without the condition correctly gets a negative test result. This leads to a tradeoff in the test's sensitivity. Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN). Because TP decrease and FN increase, the numerator decreases by more than the denominator, and the result decreases. Therefore, lowering the cutoff value in this test decreases sensitivity, making it less likely that a patient with the condition correctly gets a positive test result.

NPV = TN/(TN + FN). Because both TN and FN increase, the numerator increases by less than the denominator, and the result decreases. Therefore, lowering the cutoff value in this test decreases NPV, making it less likely that a patient with a negative test does not have the condition. PPV = TP/(TP + FP). Because both TP and FP decrease, the numerator decreases by less than the denominator, and the result increases. Therefore, lowering the cutoff value in this test increases PPV, making it more likely that a patient with a positive test has the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L increases rather than decreases this test's specificity. In addition, it decreases the test's negative predictive value.

C) INCORRECT:

Lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L decreases this test's sensitivity. However, it decreases rather than increases the test's negative predictive value.

D) INCORRECT:

Lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L decreases rather than increases this test's sensitivity. In addition, it increases the test's positive predictive value.

E) INCORRECT:

Lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L decreases this test's sensitivity. However, it increases the test's positive predictive value.

F) INCORRECT:

Lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L increases this test's specificity. However, it increases the test's positive predictive value.
questions.hint: Remember that this is a test in which a low cutoff value is diagnostic. Lowering the cutoff value to < 115 mEq/L narrows the inclusion criteria, resulting in fewer positive results (i.e., diagnoses of severe hyponatremia).

questions.text: A research group develops a screening test for the early detection of lung cancer based on a newly discovered serum protein. A PhD student in the research group evaluates the performance of the test depending on different cutoff values of the serum protein. All patients in the study population are > 50 years of age, and each has a history of smoking of at least 30 pack years. The researcher plots the new test's sensitivity and specificity data on a receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve. The test has the best performance in identifying lung cancer in patients with a serum protein cutoff value of > 50 U/mL, for which the sensitivity of the test is 93% and the specificity is 88%. A fellow PhD research student decides to repeat the study using the same screening test with the same cutoff value in patients aged < 50 years without a history of smoking. In this patient group, significantly fewer patients have lung cancer. Which of the points on the graph best represents the performance of the test in this patient group?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Point A represents an increase in the cutoff value for the new serum protein to levels substantially > 50 U/mL. A cutoff value substantially > 50 U/mL identifies fewer patients as positive for lung cancer and thereby increases specificity (i.e., more true negatives and fewer false positives) but also reduces sensitivity, (i.e., fewer true positives). However, the cutoff value was not changed for the second study.

B) CORRECT:

In a ROC curve, the y-axis represents sensitivity (i.e., the true positive rate), and the x-axis represents 1 - specificity (i.e., the false positive rate). If the same test is used in a subsequent study, the ROC curve is identical to the curve in the original study. Because the prevalence of a disease does not affect the sensitivity or specificity of a test, and the cutoff value remains unchanged (i.e., > 50 U/mL), the point on the ROC curve depicting the sensitivity and specificity of the test also remains unchanged (i.e., point B with a sensitivity of 0.93 and a specificity of 0.88, or 1 - specificity of 0.12).
Image Description:

The ROC curve illustrates the relationship between the sensitivity and specificity of a test.

The more closely the curve follows the Y axis, the more accurate the test. The more close the curve is to the diagonal dotted line (x = y), the less accurate the test.

When choosing a cutoff value, an upward shift on the ROC curve indicates increased sensitivity, and a shift to the right indicates decreased specificity.

C) INCORRECT:

Point C represents a decrease in the cutoff value of the new serum protein to levels < 50 U/mL. A cutoff value of < 50 U/mL identifies more patients with lung cancer and thereby increases sensitivity, (i.e., more true positives and fewer false negatives) but also reduces specificity (i.e., more false positives). However, the cutoff value was not changed for the second study.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in prevalence does not affect the general course of a ROC curve. Because the second study uses the same diagnostic test, there is no change in the ROC curve.

E) INCORRECT:

A curve that is near or on the diagonal line (i.e., the line of no discrimination) indicates a nondiagnostic or useless study. On this line, sensitivity is 1 - specificity, and the positive likelihood ratio is 1. A diagnostic test with this ROC curve is no better than chance and yields positive or negative results that are entirely unrelated to true disease status. A decrease in prevalence does not affect the general course of a ROC curve. Because the second study uses the same diagnostic test, there is no change in the ROC curve.
questions.hint: Although the prevalence of lung cancer is lower in the second study, some test characteristics are not influenced by changes in pretest probability.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the urgent care center after testing negative for HIV. She recently had sexual intercourse for the first time and had used a condom with her long-term boyfriend. She has no history of serious illness or sexually transmitted infections. However, the patient is still worried about the possibility she has HIV despite the negative HIV test. She states that the package insert of the HIV test shows that of 100 patients who are found to be HIV-positive on PCR, 91 tested positive via the HIV test. Later in the day, a 23-year-old woman with a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection also comes to the urgent care center after testing negative for HIV. She states that she recently had unprotected intercourse with “someone who might have HIV.” If the test is conducted on the 23-year-old patient, how will its performance compare to the test conducted on the 17-year-old patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensitivity is an intrinsic property of the screening test and does not vary based on test subjects' pretest probability of disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Validity is a term that refers to the degree of sensitivity and specificity of a given test. These are intrinsic properties of the test that would not be affected by the subjects' pretest probability of disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Specificity is an intrinsic property of the screening test and does not vary based on test subjects' pretest probability of disease.

D) INCORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability of truly having a disease after testing positive. Since the 23-year-old patient has a higher pretest probability of disease, the PPV would be increased, not decreased.

E) CORRECT:

Pretest probability does not influence intrinsic test characteristics, i.e., sensitivity, specificity, negative likelihood ratio, and positive likelihood ratio, but influences posttest probabilities, i.e., negative and positive predictive values. The negative predictive value (NPV) is inversely related to pretest probability; NPV decreases as pretest probability increases. The positive predictive value (PPV) is directly related to pretest probability; PPV increases as the pretest probability increases.
questions.hint: Given her sexual history (previous sexually transmitted infections, unprotected sexual intercourse with a partner who might have HIV), the 23-year-old patient has a higher pretest probability compared to the 17-year-old patient.

questions.text:
A rapid diagnostic test has been developed amid a major avian influenza outbreak in Asia. The outbreak has reached epidemic levels with a very high attack rate. Epidemiologists are hoping to identify all infected individuals and curb the rapid spread of disease by isolating infected patients. The epidemiologists compared rapid diagnostic test results to seropositivity of viral antigen via PCR in 200 patients. The findings are represented in the following table:


Test result
PCR-confirmed avian influenza
No avian influenza



Positive rapid diagnostic test
95
2


Negative rapid diagnostic test
5
98



Based on these results, the epidemiologists decide to use the rapid diagnostic test as the initial test in the serial testing strategy. Which of the following characteristics of the rapid diagnostic test best explains this decision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sensitivity of a test refers to its true positive rate. It is calculated by dividing the number of patients with the disease who screened positive by the total number of diseased patients. The sensitivity of the test above is not 98%.

B) INCORRECT:

The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that a patient who screens negative for the disease truly does not have the disease. For a sample population, it is calculated by dividing the number of disease-free patients who screened negative by the total number of people who screened negative. The NPV for the test in the sample population is not 95/97.

C) INCORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that a patient who screens positive actually has the disease. For a sample population, it is calculated by dividing the number of people with the disease who screened positive by the total number of people that screened positive. The PPV of the test in the sample population is not 96/101.

D) INCORRECT:

The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that a patient who screens negative for the disease truly does not have the disease and 98/103 is the correct value of NPV for the sample population (100 patients with influenza and 100 without influenza). However, the true NPV is affected by the point prevalence of influenza in the general population. The researcher based their decision on a test characteristic that is independent of the point prevalence of influenza in the general population.

E) INCORRECT:

The specificity of a test refers to its true negative rate. It is calculated by dividing the number of disease-free patients who screened negative by the total number of disease-free patients. The specificity of the test above is not 95%.

F) INCORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that a patient who screens positive actually has the disease and 95/97 is the correct value of PPV for the sample population (100 patients with influenza and 100 without influenza). However, PPV is not a determinant of the usefulness of a screening test. Moreover, the true PPV is affected by the point prevalence of influenza in the general population.

G) INCORRECT:

Specificity refers to a test's true negative rate. Specificity is more important for a confirmatory test, which is the second step in a serial testing strategy when the purpose is to arrive at an unequivocal diagnosis. Although it has been correctly calculated as 98/100, specificity is not the most important characteristic for a screening test.

H) CORRECT:

High sensitivity is the most important characteristic for a screening test. The priority of a screening test is to detect as many affected patients as possible. The risk of a false positive result (which is related to specificity) is, therefore, less important than minimizing the number of false negatives. In a test with high sensitivity, a negative test result helps to rule out disease. High specificity, on the other hand, is the most important characteristic for a confirmatory test.

Sensitivity and specificity, which are test characteristics, are independent of prevalence in the general population (pretest probability). A high sensitivity correlates with a high negative predictive value (NPV) and a high specificity correlates with a high positive predictive value (PPV). However, NPV and PPV, which are posttest probabilities, are also dependent on the condition's prevalence. If the prevalence of a condition in the general population is not represented in the sample population, the NPV and PPV calculated for the sample population do not have external validity.
questions.hint: A serial testing strategy uses a screening test followed by a confirmatory test. The investigators have chosen the rapid diagnostic test as a screening test.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of nocturia. He wakes up twice each night to urinate. He has no involuntary leakage of urine and no history of serious illness. He takes no medication. His younger brother was diagnosed with testicular cancer at the age of 35 years. Rectal examination shows a smooth, symmetrical prostate without nodules. The remainder of the examination and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Bladder ultrasonography discloses a postvoid residual volume of 10 mL (N < 50). The physician offers to discuss the advantages and limitations of the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test in screening for prostate cancer. He mentions that a serum PSA of 4 ng/mL is generally used as a cutoff value. At this cutoff, the test has a sensitivity of 21% for detecting any prostate cancer and 51% for detecting high-risk prostate cancer, with a specificity of 91%. In patients without urinary retention, hematuria, back pain, or incontinence, the positive predictive value (PPV) for PSA > 4 ng/mL is estimated at 30%, and the negative predictive value (NPV) for PSA ≤ 4 ng/mL at 85%. Based on this information, what is the probability that this patient does not have prostate cancer if his PSA is 4.3 ng/mL?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

21% is the sensitivity, true positive rate, or P (positive test | disease). It is the probability that a patient with prostate cancer will have a positive test.

B) INCORRECT:

79% is the false negative rate or P (negative test | disease). It is the probability that a patient with prostate cancer will test negative. It is calculated as 100% minus sensitivity: 100% - 21% = 79%.

C) INCORRECT:

85% is the negative predictive value (NPV) or P (no disease | negative test). It is the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease. This relatively high NPV is the strength of the PSA screening test; if the test is negative, the patient is very unlikely to have prostate cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

15% is the probability that a patient truly does have prostate cancer despite a negative test result, i.e., P (disease | negative test). It is calculated as 100% minus the negative predictive value: 100% - 85% = 15%.

E) INCORRECT:

30% is the PPV. The relatively low PPV indicates that a large proportion of the positive results from this screening test are false positives.

F) CORRECT:

The probability that a patient who tests positive truly does not have the disease, i.e., P (no disease | positive test), is calculated as 100% minus the PPV: 100% - 30% = 70%. Of those patients without urinary retention, hematuria, back pain, or incontinence who test positive, 70% do not have prostate cancer (false positives with, e.g., benign prostatic hyperplasia, prostatitis, perineal trauma), while 30% do have prostate cancer (true positives).

This patient's symptom of nocturia could be related to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH); PSA has poor discriminatory ability in men with symptomatic BPH. Because of the high false-positive rate, a PSA > 4 ng/mL should be followed by a test with a higher validity (ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy) in order to find out if the patient is truly affected. Other methods of increasing the validity of the PSA include examining the PSA as a quotient of the prostate volume (PSA density), the evolution of the PSA over time (PSA velocity), and the ratio of free PSA to bound PSA.

G) INCORRECT:

9% is the false positive rate or P (positive test | no disease). It is the probability that a patient without prostate cancer will test positive. It is calculated as 100% minus specificity: 100% - 91% = 9%.
questions.hint: In this scenario, PSA values are used as a test for prostate cancer with a value above the cutoff of 4 ng/mL being considered a positive test and a value ≤ 4 ng/mL considered a negative test. The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a patient who tests positive truly does have the disease of interest, i.e., P (disease | positive test) when expressed as a conditional probability.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman comes to a medical school's free clinic for follow-up examination after a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is seen by a fourth-year medical student. The clinic serves largely uninsured low-income patients in a New York City neighborhood with a large African American and Latino population. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated in the local emergency department where she presented with an altered mental state and dysuria. The medical student had recently read about a study that described a strong relationship between cognitive impairment and UTI hospitalization risk (RR = 1.34, p < 0.001). The attending physician at the medical student's free clinic is also familiar with this study and tells the medical student that the study was conducted in a sample of upper-middle-class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands. The attending states that the results of the study should be interpreted with caution. Which of the following concerns is most likely underlying the attending physician's remarks?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no information presented that would support confounding bias, i.e., the existence of a third variable affecting both cognitive impairment and UTI hospitalization risk, thus providing an alternative explanation for the observed relationship between the two variables.

B) INCORRECT:

Internal validity refers to how well a study was conducted and how correct are a study's inferences about a phenomena being evaluated for the population studied. Often, internal validity refers to whether researchers have been successful in controlling for the effects of possible confounding variables in a relationship being investigated. There is no evidence in the question stem about flaws in study design.

C) INCORRECT:

Reliability refers to similar results being produced under consistent conditions. If the relationship described in this question stem between cognitive impairment and UTI hospitalization risk were not replicable in the same upper Middle class population in the Netherlands, one could posit that the study's results were unreliable. However, there is no evidence of this being the case.

D) INCORRECT:

The definition of precision in statistics refers to how close repeated measures are to each other. There is no evidence of high variance (statistics) and/or standard deviations that may hint at a lack of precision in a study being conducted.

E) CORRECT:

External validity refers to whether data from a study's sample can be applied to a real-world population outside of the study's confines. In this case, the results of a study conducted in an upper-middle-class Caucasian sample may not be generalizable to a low-income African American/Latino sample given marked differences in the research study's target demographics in comparison to the biopsychosocial characteristics of the population surrounding the student clinic.

F) INCORRECT:

Selection bias occurs if study subjects are inappropriately selected or a large number of patients is lost to follow-up. There is no evidence that the European study investigating the association between cognitive impairment and UTI hospitalization risk recruited an inappropriate sample for their outcome of interest in their target population.
questions.hint: The study was conducted in an upper-middle-class Caucasian sample in the Netherlands while the medical student's clinic is situated in a largely African American and Latino enclave in New York City.

The results of the two studies are summarized in the table.
