Based on these results, which of the following statements about the risk of lymphoma is most accurate?

choices.text: The risk is higher in study B because the prevalence in study B is 9 cases per 300 patients
The risk is higher in study A because the incidence rate in study A is 30 cases per 10 person-years
The risks are equivalent because the prevalence in both studies is 39 cases per 3300 persons
The risks are equivalent because the incidence rate in both studies is 1 case per 1000 person-years
The risk is higher in study A because the prevalence in study A is 30 cases per 3000 patients
The risk is higher in study B because the cumulative incidence in study B is 9 cases per 300 patients

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

B) INCORRECT:

The incidence rate of study A is not 30 cases per 10 person-years. It is crucial to consider the number of people observed (3000 patients) when measuring the incidence rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

D) CORRECT:

The incidence rate (IR) or person-time rate is a measure of risk that can be used when comparing groups with different followup periods. IR = (number of new cases)/(total person-time observation).

The total person-time observation for a study is the time each person was observed, totaled for all persons in the study. Alternatively, total person-time observation = (number of people observed) × (mean followup period).

The IR in study A is (30 cases)/(3000 persons × 10 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IR in study B is (9 cases)/(300 persons × 30 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IRs in both studies are the same and the risk is therefore equivalent.

Absolute risk (AR), which is the likelihood of an event occurring under specific conditions, is equivalent to cumulative incidence or incidence proportion (IP). IP = (number of new cases in a specific time period)/(number of people at risk). AR or IP is not a useful measure of risk when the followup periods are different.

E) INCORRECT:

Prevalence generally does not allow conclusions to be drawn about risk. The exception is for diseases of very short duration (e.g., acute food poisoning), in which prevalence and incidence have approximately the same value.

F) INCORRECT:

It is crucial to consider the differences in observation periods (10 years versus 30 years) and sample size (3000 versus 300 patients) when using measures of risk. The absolute risk (AR), which is equivalent to cumulative incidence or incidence proportion, is higher in study B (9 in 300 or 0.03) than in study A (30 in 3000 or 0.01) but these are not the appropriate measures to compare risk when studies have different followup periods.
questions.hint: An appropriately chosen measure of incidence indicates the risk of developing a condition.

questions.text: An academic medical center has been using fasting plasma levels ≥ 25 nmol/L of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) as a marker for possible carcinoid tumors. The clinicians at the hospital have recently noticed that many patients with 5-HIAA plasma levels < 25 nmol/L have been diagnosed with carcinoid tumors through other diagnostic tests such as 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA, serum serotonin, histamine, and chromogranin tests. The clinicians are interested in modifying the plasma 5-HIAA cutoff value to minimize false negatives. They have subsequently identified various cutoff values, labeled in the graph shown. Which of the following cutoffs is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the cutoff value represented by A results in maximal sensitivity by reducing the false-negative rate to effectively zero, it decreases the test's specificity by significantly increasing the false-positive rate. A different cutoff value results in an equally sensitive but more specific test.

B) CORRECT:

Every diagnostic test involves a trade-off between sensitivity and specificity. Given the priorities of the clinicians, the cutoff value represented by B is most appropriate because it achieves maximal sensitivity by reducing the false negative rate to effectively zero without completely compromising specificity. Using this cutoff value, almost all individuals with carcinoid tumors will test positive, and approximately half of the patients without carcinoid tumors will test negative.
Image Description:

Graph showing the sensitivity and specificity of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: positive test result; red: negative test result)

– True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
– True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
– False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
– False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the disease

The cutoff value of the diagnostic test includes all the TPs (and no FNs), indicating that it is a highly sensitive test.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the cutoff value represented by C increases sensitivity by reducing the false-negative rate, another option will result in even higher sensitivity.

D) INCORRECT:

The cutoff value represented by D increases specificity by reducing the false-positive rate. However, because the clinicians are prioritizing increased sensitivity, another option is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the cutoff value represented by E results in maximal specificity by reducing the false-positive rate to effectively zero, it significantly decreases the test's sensitivity. Because the clinicians are prioritizing increased sensitivity, another option is more appropriate.

F) INCORRECT:

Although the cutoff value represented by F results in maximal specificity by reducing the false-positive rate to effectively zero, it significantly decreases the test's sensitivity. Because the clinicians are prioritizing increased sensitivity, another option is more appropriate.
Image Description:

Graph showing the results of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: positive test result; red: negative test result)

- True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
- True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
- False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
- False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the disease

The cutoff value (i.e., the threshold at which a test is considered positive or negative) determines the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a test. Here, the cutoff value of the diagnostic test includes all the TNs (and no FPs), indicating that this is a highly specific test.
questions.hint: Reducing the false-negative rate increases the sensitivity of a test.

He conducts a study in which he identifies 200 patients with psoriasis and 200 patients without psoriasis. The patients are matched with regard to their age and comorbidities and are followed for 10 years. At the end of this period, participants' charts are reviewed for myocardial infarction during this time interval.

What is the 10-year risk of myocardial infarction in participants with psoriasis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

0.5 or 50% is the prevalence of exposure (here: psoriasis cases) in the entire cohort: 200/400 = 0.5.

B) INCORRECT:

0.75 or 75% is the prevalence of psoriasis in patients with myocardial infarction (MI), which is calculated as the total number of patients with myocardial infarction and psoriasis divided by the total number of patients with myocardial infarction: 12/16 = 0.75. In other words, 75% of patients with MI had psoriasis.

C) CORRECT:

The probability of having a myocardial infarction (MI) in participants with psoriasis over the 10-year time period is 0.06 or 6%. The absolute risk is equivalent to the cumulative incidence (i.e., incidence proportion), which is the number of new cases per population at risk in a given time period. Here, there were 12 new cases of MI in 200 participants with psoriasis (12/200 = 0.06) during the follow-up period of 10 years.

D) INCORRECT:

0.04 or 4% is the absolute risk of all patients (with and without psoriasis) developing myocardial infarction (MI) over the observation period of 10 years. Here, there were 16 new cases of MI in the total population of 400 participants during the 10-year follow-up period: 16/400 = 0.04.

E) INCORRECT:

3.0 is the relative risk but not the absolute risk of myocardial infarction (MI) in participants with psoriasis. The relative risk is calculated as the probability of MI in the exposed group (i.e., with psoriasis) divided by the probability of MI in the control group (i.e., no psoriasis): (12/200)/(4/200) = 3.0. A relative risk > 1.0 indicates a positive association between psoriasis and myocardial infarction.

F) INCORRECT:

0.02 or 2% is the absolute risk of patients without psoriasis developing myocardial infarction (MI) over the observation time of 10 years. Here, there were 4 new cases of MI in the control group of 200 participants without psoriasis during the 10-year follow-up period: 4/200 = 0.02.
questions.hint: Absolute risk is the probability of developing a certain disease over time.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with congestive heart failure comes to the office because of a 1-year history of shortness of breath and fatigue. He says that he has to take breaks from his usual daily activities like cooking or cleaning to catch his breath. Six months ago, he was hospitalized for acute decompensation of heart failure and his medication was adjusted. He says that he has had difficulties remembering his medication regimen. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide, spironolactone, and metformin. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pulse is 89/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting pretibial edema bilaterally. Auscultation of the lungs discloses bibasilar mild crackles. Transthoracic echocardiography shows increased sizes of the left atrium and ventricle, diastolic dysfunction, and a left ventricular ejection fraction of approximately 0.55. The physician has recently read a pharmaceutical advertisement for a new drug for heart failure called MelliFly and considers prescribing this medication to the patient. Based on the pharmaceutical advertisement shown, which of the following statements about MelliFly is most appropriate with regard to this patient?

choices.text: MelliFly should not be prescribed because of potential drug interactions with this patient's other medications
MelliFly should be prescribed to this patient because of its simple dosing regimen
MelliFly should not be prescribed because the advertisement does not feature this patient's clinical syndrome
MelliFly should not be prescribed because its side effect profile is unfavorable for this patient
MelliFly should be prescribed because it effectively lowers this patient's risk of hospitalization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Safety concerns (e.g., potential interactions) should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. Pharmaceutical advertisements typically feature a safety warnings box that includes information about potential drug interactions and important risks, which should be weighed against the potential benefits of the drug. This patient takes a thiazide diuretic, an aldosterone receptor antagonist, and the biguanide metformin, none of which is mentioned in the safety warnings box of the advertisement.

B) INCORRECT:

The simplicity of a treatment regimen should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. This patient has difficulties remembering his regimen and may benefit from a once-daily medication. However, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering the dosing regimen.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a history of congestive heart failure and an ejection fraction (EF) of 55%, which indicates that he has heart failure with preserved EF. The advertisement states that the medicine is targeted at patients with heart failure with reduced EF (i.e., with an EF of < 40%). The medication does not address this patient's specific condition, so it would not be appropriate to prescribe it.

After a clear definition of a patient's problem (e.g., “congestive heart failure with preserved EF, NYHA III”), the goal of prescribing a drug should be determined (e.g., “improvement of dyspnea and fatigue”). This step is followed by a systematic evaluation of all treatment options, including nonpharmacological options. The options can be compared with regard to their safety (e.g., interactions, contraindications), tolerability (e.g., side effect profile), effectiveness (e.g., maximum expected effect on symptoms), price (e.g., monthly costs), and simplicity (e.g., frequency of dosing regimen). Some of this information can be found in pharmaceutical advertisements (e.g., in the safety warnings box), whereas other information does not need to be included (e.g., price). The patient should be provided with information on the chosen treatment, instructions on the use, and potential safety warnings. Finally, the treatment and its effect should be reevaluated on a regular basis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tolerability (e.g., side effects) should be taken into account when prescribing a drug. Pharmaceutical advertisements typically mention the most important side effects, which should be considered in relation to the patient's medical history and preferences. Poor tolerability may outweigh the benefits of a drug. In this patient, the benefits of treatment with the new drug (overall improved outcome of heart failure) would outweigh the risks and relative frequencies of side effects (e.g., hypoglycemia, urinary tract infections). Furthermore, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering its tolerability.

E) INCORRECT:

Effectiveness should be taken into account when prescribing a drug to a patient. The risk of hospitalization for heart failure is effectively lowered by the drug in the advertisement and the results of the study are statistically significant (HR = 0.63, p < 0.001). However, another aspect of the drug has to be evaluated before considering its effectiveness for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has heart failure with marked limitations of physical activity (i.e., NYHA class III). When prescribing a medication to a patient, the physician should follow a systematic approach and first consider the patient's individual problem.

questions.text: Which of the following interpretations can be made correctly from the graph on progressive renal disease in the pharmaceutical advertisement (page 2)?

choices.text: The incidence rate of progressive renal disease for both groups increased over the time of the study period
At the end of the study period, more than 50% of patients in the placebo group had developed progressive renal disease compared to less than 50% in the treatment group
The graph should not be used for treatment decisions because cumulative incidence is not sufficient to allow inferences to be made about the risk for an individual patient

At the end of the study period, the risk of having developed progressive renal disease in the treatment group was approximately 1.5% lower than the risk of progressive renal disease in the placebo group
Treatment with MelliFly reduced the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease by 28% over the time of the study period

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The cumulative incidence (displayed on the y-axis) of progressive renal disease increased for both groups over the time of the study period. However, the incidence rate (i.e., the rate at which new cases developed divided by the total time that participants were observed) is not shown. Incidence rate is measured in person-years, whereas cumulative incidence is a proportion.

B) INCORRECT:

The y-axis of this graph shows a maximum value for the cumulative incidence of 0.10 (i.e., 10%). The risk of developing progressive renal disease at the end of the study period is more than 5% in the placebo group and less than 5% in the treatment group.

C) INCORRECT:

Cumulative incidence, the proportion of new cases of a given disease in a specific time period in all individuals at risk of contracting that disease at the start of the period, can be used to estimate an individual's risk of developing a disease. Cumulative incidence does not account for patients lost to follow-up or who are no longer at risk because they already developed the outcome, so this measure tends to underestimate the true rate of new cases. Nevertheless, cumulative incidence provides an estimate that can be used for treatment decisions.

D) CORRECT:

The y-axis displays the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease, which can be used as an estimate of the risk of developing a disease. At the end of the study period, the cumulative incidence (i.e., risk of having developed progressive renal disease) was 0.057 in the placebo group and 0.041 in the treatment group. Therefore, the absolute risk reduction at the end of the study period is: risk in unexposed - risk in exposed = 0.057 - 0.041 = 0.016 (1.6%). Note that in this advertisement, the maximum value of the y-axis is not 1.0 (i.e., 100%), but 0.10 (i.e., 10%). The resulting graph may be misinterpreted and give a false impression of the treatment effect.

In the title above the graph, the advertisement highlights a risk reduction for progressive renal disease of 28%, which is the risk reduction of the treatment group relative to placebo (relative risk reduction: 1 - 0.041 /0.057= 0.28).

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with MelliFly reduced the cumulative incidence of progressive renal disease by 28%, but only in relation to the placebo. This difference is the relative risk reduction (RRR = 1 - hazard ratio) and is not equivalent to stating that treatment reduced the cumulative incidence by 28% (absolute risk reduction).
questions.hint: When interpreting a graph, it is important to identify the variables (x-axis and y-axis), the units, and the scaling and maximum values of each axis.

questions.text: A public health campaign increases vaccination rates against human papillomaviruses 16 and 18. Increased vaccination rates would have which of the following effects on the Papanicolaou test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

True negative rate (specificity) is not influenced by the prevalence of the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

True positive rate (sensitivity) is not influenced by the prevalence of a disease.

C) CORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is directly proportional to prevalence. Therefore, PPV decreases as the prevalence of a disease decreases.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive likelihood ratio is not influenced by the prevalence of a disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Negative likelihood ratio is not influenced by the prevalence of a disease.

F) INCORRECT:

The negative predictive value (NPV) of a test is inversely proportional to disease prevalence. In this case increasing the HPV vaccination rate would decrease the prevalence of the disease, which, in turn, would increase the NPV.
questions.hint: Increasing the rate of HPV vaccination would decrease the number of new cases of cervical cancer, thereby decreasing disease prevalence.

Based on the table, the absence of which clinical finding would most accurately rule out appendicitis in this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

Guarding has the highest specificity (0.85) of all the clinical findings presented. A measure or test with high specificity will very likely be negative in a person who does not have the disease (i.e., high true negative rate) and is thus most useful for confirming a diagnosis after a positive screening test. Therefore, tests with high specificity are used to confirm rather than rule out a disease.

B) CORRECT:

In the table, fever has the highest sensitivity (0.80) for acute appendicitis in children under the age of 2 years. If a highly sensitive test (e.g., core body temperature) yields a negative result (e.g., afebrile), the disease can be more reliably ruled out. Thus, tests with high sensitivity are often used for screening purposes.

Abdominal rebound, which has even higher sensitivity, has only been assessed in children ≥ 5 years of age and can therefore not be used in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Anorexia has the lowest specificity for acute appendicitis out of the clinical findings presented in the table. A test with a low specificity means that the feature being tested is more likely to be present in individuals who do not have the disease (i.e., high false positive rate). Therefore, even if this patient had no history of anorexia, appendicitis could not be confidently ruled out.

D) INCORRECT:

Rebound would be the correct answer if the patient were over 5 years of age, as it has high sensitivity in this age group. This patient is only 1 year of age, and the table does not present data on the role of rebound tenderness in the evaluation of appendicitis in individuals < 5 years of age. Therefore, a negative test result for rebound would not help to rule out appendicitis in this child.

E) INCORRECT:

Vomiting has the lowest sensitivity (0.40) for appendicitis out of all the clinical findings presented. A test with a low sensitivity means that the feature being tested is less likely to be present in individuals who have the disease. Therefore, even if this patient had no history of vomiting, appendicitis could not be confidently ruled out.
questions.hint: A clinical finding with a high true positive rate for appendicitis can be used as a screening test for appendicitis in this patient, who is 1 year of age.

A researcher is investigating the risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage associated with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) treatment in severe ischemic stroke. The outcomes of a large randomized controlled trial of ischemic stroke patients, some of whom were randomized to tPA, is shown:



Symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage
No symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage



Received tPA
12
188


Did not receive tPA
25
475



Based on this data, how many patients with severe ischemic stroke would need to be treated with tPA, on average, to contribute to one case of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This calculation is based on the risk of symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage in the tPA group (12/200 = 0.06). In order to compare the two groups, the correct equation must also consider the risk of symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage in the control group.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the number of patients in the tPA group that did not experience a hemorrhage. The correct equation focuses on those afflicted with an intracerebral hemorrhage and also account for both the tPA and the control groups.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the difference in symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage cases between the tPA group and control group. This calculation is incorrect because it doesn't account for the size difference between the tPA group compared to the control group. A much greater number of patients did not receive tPA.

D) INCORRECT:

This value approximates the odds ratio. Although an odds ratio is useful in case-control studies and quantifies risk, the resulting calculation is the odds of intracerebral hemorrhage between two groups. Instead, the intended result for this question is in units of people.

E) CORRECT:

Attributable risk = Incidence risk(exposed) - Incidence risk(unexposed) = proportion of the exposed who developed the outcome - proportion of the unexposed who developed the outcome. From the results of the study, the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage attributable to tPA = intracerebral hemorrhage risk among tPA group - intracerebral hemorrhage risk in control group = [12/(12 + 188) - 25/(25 + 475)] = (12/200) - (25/500) = 0.01.

NNH = 1 / (attributable risk) = 1/0.01 = 100

100 patients with severe ischemic stroke would need to receive tPA to cause one patient to suffer from a symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage.
questions.hint: The value of interest is the number needed to harm (NNH). It can be calculated as the inverse of attributable risk.

questions.text:
A group of researchers studying the relationship between major depressive disorder and unprovoked seizures identified 36 patients via chart review who had been rehospitalized for unprovoked seizures following discharge from an inpatient psychiatric unit and 105 patients recently discharged from the same unit who did not experience unprovoked seizures. The results of the study show:



Unprovoked seizure
No seizure



Major depressive disorder
20
35


No major depressive disorder
16
70



Based on this information, which of the following is the most appropriate measure of association between history of major depressive disorder (MDD) and unprovoked seizures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

[20/(20 +35)] = 0.36 would represent the risk of unprovoked seizures among patients with MDD if this was a cohort study. However, since case-control studies only sample a subset of all possible disease-free people as controls, the actual incidence of disease and, therefore, also the incidence risk cannot usually be calculated directly. The appropriate statistical measure in a case-control study compares odds, not risks.

B) INCORRECT:

[20/(20 +35)] / [16/(16 +70)] = 1.95 would represent the relative risk of seizures among psychiatric inpatients with MDD against those without MDD if this was a cohort study. However, since case-control studies only sample a subset of all possible disease-free people as controls, the actual incidence of disease and, therefore, also the relative risk cannot usually be calculated directly. The appropriate statistical measure in a case-control study compares odds, not risks.

C) INCORRECT:

[20/16] = 1.25 is the odds of MDD among patients with unprovoked seizures. While odds are commonly calculated in case-control studies, by only comparing exposure (with MDD) and nonexposure (no MDD) among cases (unprovoked seizures), one does not leverage all of the information provided in this study. The most appropriate statistical measure of association in this study also takes into account controls (no seizures).

D) CORRECT:

The odds of a patient with unprovoked seizure having a history of major depressive disorder (i.e., exposure odds) is the ratio of the number of patients with MDD who develop an unprovoked seizure (a = 20) to the number of patients without MDD who developed an unprovoked seizure (c = 16). Similarly, the odds of patients without seizures having a history of MDD is 35 (= b) divided by 70 (= d). The odds ratio of exposure is calculated as: (a/c) / (b/d) = ad/bc = (20*70)/(35*16) = 2.5. Based on this study, the odds of a patient with an unprovoked seizure having a history of MDD is 2.5 times higher when compared to patients without seizures.

The odds of an unprovoked seizure in a patient with MDD, i.e., event odds (disease odds), is the ratio of the number of patients with MDD who develop an unprovoked seizure (a = 20) to the number of patients with MDD who did not develop an unprovoked seizure (b = 35). Similarly, the odds of a seizure in a patient without MDD is 16 (= c) divided by 70 (= d). Consequently, the odds ratio of disease is calculated as: (a/b) / (c/d) = ad/bc = (20*70)/(35*16) = 2.5. As one can see, the odds ratio of disease and the odds ratio of exposure have the same value and are often used interchangeably in practice.

E) INCORRECT:

[20/(20 +35)] - [16/(16 +70)] = 0.17 would represent the difference between the risks of unprovoked seizures of patients with MDD and without MDD (attributable risk) if this was a cohort study. However, since case-control studies only sample a subset of all possible disease-free people as controls, the actual incidence of disease and, therefore, also the attributable risk cannot usually be calculated. The appropriate way to compare odds, which should be used instead of risks in a case-control study, is through a ratio (division) rather than a difference (subtraction).
questions.hint: The researchers began the study by identifying patients with or without the outcome (unprovoked seizures) and then determined the presence or absence of the potential exposure (major depressive disorder; MDD). This study design is consistent with a case-control study. The appropriate measure of association in a case-control study is the odds ratio.

questions.text:
A randomized controlled trial is conducted to evaluate the relationship between the angiotensin receptor blocker losartan and cardiovascular death in patients with heart failure (diagnosed as ejection fraction < 30%) who are already being treated with an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and a beta blocker. Patients are randomized either to losartan (N = 1500) or placebo (N = 1400). The results of the study show:



Cardiovascular death
No cardiovascular death



Losartan + ACE inhibitor + beta blocker
300
1200


Placebo + ACE inhibitor + beta blocker
350
1050



Based on this information, if 200 patients with heart failure and an ejection fraction < 30% were treated with losartan in addition to an ACE inhibitor and a beta blocker, on average, how many cases of cardiovascular death would be prevented?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This value is the number needed to treat, which is calculated by taking the inverse of the ARR. In this study, the ARR is the risk in the placebo group, 350 / (350 + 1050) = 0.25, minus the risk in the losartan group, 300 / (300 + 1200) = 0.20. Thus, the ARR = 0.25 - 0.20 = 0.05. The NNT is therefore 1/0.05 = 20 patients. However, the question asks how many deaths will be prevented if 200 patients with heart failure and an ejection fraction < 30% were treated with losartan in addition to an ACE inhibitor and a beta blocker.

B) CORRECT:

The absolute risk reduction in this study is the risk in the placebo group, 350 / (350 + 1050) = 0.25, minus the risk in the losartan group, 300 / (300 + 1200) = 0.20. Thus, the ARR = 0.25 - 0.20 = 0.05. Therefore, the number needed to treat is 1/0.05 = 20 patients. This means that for every 20 patients treated, one death will be prevented. For every 200 patients treated, 10 deaths will be prevented.

C) INCORRECT:

This value is the risk of cardiovascular death in the placebo group, which is calculated by dividing the number of deaths in the placebo group by the number at risk in the placebo group: 350 / (350 + 1050) = 0.25.

D) INCORRECT:

This value is the difference in the number of cardiovascular deaths in the placebo group (350) and the losartan group (300). This does not relate to the number of deaths that would be prevented if 200 patients with heart failure and an ejection fraction < 30% were treated with losartan in addition to an ACE inhibitor and a beta blocker.

E) INCORRECT:

This value is the absolute risk reduction. In this study, the ARR is the risk in the placebo group, 350 / (350 + 1050) = 0.25, minus the risk in the losartan group, 300 / (300 + 1200) = 0.20. Thus, the ARR = 0.25 - 0.20 = 0.05.
questions.hint: To answer this question correctly, first calculate the number needed to treat (NNT) (i.e., the number of individuals that must be treated for one person to benefit from treatment), which is the inverse of absolute risk reduction (1/ARR). Then, as the second step, consider that the question asks for the number of persons who would benefit if 200 patients were treated!

questions.text:
An investigator is studying the efficacy of a new bisphosphonate analog in preventing hip fractures in patients above 60 years of age with risk factors for osteoporosis but no confirmed diagnosis. Participating patients were randomized to either pharmacologic therapy with the new bisphosphonate analog or a placebo. The results show:



Hip fracture
No hip fracture



Pharmacologic therapy
3
97


No pharmacologic therapy
10
190



Based on this information, which of the following best represents the proportionate reduction in the risk of hip fractures brought about due to pharmacologic therapy, in comparison to the control group?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This value is the risk of hip fracture in the treatment group, which is calculated as 3/(97 + 3) = 0.03.

B) INCORRECT:

This value is the risk of hip fracture in the control group, which is calculated as 10/(190 + 10) = 0.05.

C) CORRECT:

The relative risk (RR) of hip fracture in the treatment group compared to the control group is calculated as the risk of hip fracture in the treatment group [3/(97 + 3) = 0.03] divided by the risk of hip fracture in the control group [10/(190 + 10) = 0.05]. 0.03/0.05 = 0.6 = 60%. The relative risk reduction, RRR = 1 - RR, thus equals 1 - 0.6 = 0.4, which indicates a 40% reduction in the risk of hip fracture due to the pharmacologic therapy compared to control.

Drug advertisements often use measures of relative risk because they tend to overestimate the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention. In the case of this new bisphosphonate analog, the drug company is likely to promote the 40% reduction in relative risk rather than the 2% reduction in absolute risk.

D) INCORRECT:

This value is the absolute risk reduction, which is the risk in the control group minus the risk in the treatment group. In this study, the ARR equals [10/(190 + 10) = 0.05] minus [3/(97 + 3) = 0.03]. 0.05 - 0.03 = 0.02 = 2%.

E) INCORRECT:

This value is the relative risk of hip fracture in the treatment group compared to the control group, which is calculated as the risk of hip fracture in the treatment group [3/(97 + 3) = 0.03] divided by the risk of hip fracture in the control group [10/(190 + 10) = 0.05]. 0.03/0.05 = 0.6 = 60%. However, this value is not the reduction in risk due to the pharmacologic therapy.
questions.hint: The value of interest is the relative risk reduction (RRR), which is calculated by subtracting the relative risk (RR) from 1 (i.e., RRR = 1 - RR).

The investigator evaluates the effect of a ban on aldicarb, an especially neurotoxic pesticide of the carbamate class. The ban aims to reduce pesticide poisonings attributable to carbamates. The investigator followed 1,000 agricultural workers residing in Central American towns that banned aldicarb as well as 2,000 agricultural workers residing in communities that continued to use aldicarb over a period of 5 years. The results show:

Which of the following values corresponds to the difference in risk attributable to the ban on aldicarb?

A) CORRECT:

The event rate of pesticide poisonings in the group that did not ban aldicarb is 100/2000. The event rate of pesticide poisonings in the group with the aldicarb ban is 10/1000. Therefore, the absolute risk reduction = (100/2000) - (10/1000) = 0.05 - 0.01 = 0.04 or 4%.

B) INCORRECT:

This value is the relative risk (RR), which is the event rate in the group with exposure to the intervention divided by the event rate in the group without exposure to the intervention. In this case, RR = (10/1000) / (100/2000) = 0.01/0.05 = 0.2.

C) INCORRECT:

This value is the number needed to treat (NNT), which is the reciprocal of ARR. In this case, the NNT = 1/ [(100/2000) - (10/1000)] = 1/(0.05 - 0.01) = 25.

D) INCORRECT:

This value is the odds ratio (OR) of exposure, which is the odds of exposure to the intervention in the group with the outcome (10/100 in this case) divided by the odds of exposure to the intervention in the group without the outcome (990/1900 in this case). The OR of exposure is, therefore, (10/100) / (990/1900), which is approximately 0.19.

E) INCORRECT:

100 - 10 = 90 is simply the difference in the number of events between the group without exposure to the intervention and the group with exposure to the intervention. This is not the value of interest.

F) INCORRECT:

This value is the relative risk reduction (RRR), which is calculated with the formula 1 - relative risk (RR). The RR is the event rate in the group with exposure to the intervention divided by the event rate in the group without exposure to the intervention = (10/1000) / (100/2000) = 0.01/0.05 =0.2. Thus, the RRR = 1 - 0.2 = 0.8.
questions.hint: In this study, the outcome (event) is pesticide poisoning and the intervention is an aldicarb ban. The value of interest is the absolute risk reduction (ARR) = Absolute risk(no intervention) - Absolute risk(intervention), i.e., the difference between the event rate in the group without exposure to the intervention and the group with exposure to the intervention.

Of all the participants who do not have tuberculosis (6 + 194), the test was negative in 194 (i.e., 194 true negative results). Therefore, the specificity of this test is 194/200.

B) CORRECT:

The sensitivity of this test is calculated using the formula: true positives/(true positives + false negatives). Of all the participants who were confirmed to have tuberculosis by culture (91 + 9), the test was positive in 91 (i.e., 91 true positive results). Therefore, the sensitivity of this test is 91/100.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

In this study with 300 participants, 100 have confirmed tuberculosis. Therefore, the prevalence of tuberculosis in this cohort is 100/300.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the negative predictive value (NPV) of this test, which is calculated using the formula: true negatives/(true negatives + false negatives). Of all the participants who tested negative (i.e., 194 + 9), 194 do not have tuberculosis. Therefore, the NPV of this test is 194/203.

This is the false positive rate of this test, which is calculated with the following formula: (1 – specificity). The specificity of this test is 35/(35 + 15), which is 0.7. Therefore, the false positive rate of this test is 1 – 0.7, which is 0.3 or 30%.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the false negative rate of this test, which is calculated with the following formula: (1 – sensitivity). The sensitivity of this test is 45/(45 + 5), which is 0.9. Therefore, the false negative rate of this test is 1 – 0.9, which is 0.1 or 10%.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the negative predictive value (NPV) of this test, which is calculated with the following formula: true negatives/(true negatives + false negatives). Of all the children who had a negative test (i.e., true negatives + false negatives: 35 + 5), only 35 do not have ASD. Therefore, the NPV of this test is 35/(35 + 5), which is 35/40 or ∼ 88%.

D) CORRECT:

The specificity of a test is calculated with the following formula: true negatives/(true negatives + false positives). Of the children who do not have ASD (35 + 15), 35 tested negative (i.e., 35 true negative test results). Therefore, the specificity of this test is 35/(35 + 15), which is 35/50 or 70%.

Of all the children who have ASD (45 + 5), 45 tested positive (i.e., 45 true positive test results). Therefore, the sensitivity of this test is 45/(45 + 5), which is 45/50 or 90%.

F) INCORRECT:

Of all the children who had a positive test (i.e., true positive + false positive: 45 + 15), only 45 have ASD. Therefore, the PPV of this test is 45/(45 + 15), which is 45/60 or 75%.

A 26-year-old medical student comes to the physician with a 3-week history of night sweats and myalgias. During this time, he has also had 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss. He returned from a 6-month tropical medicine rotation in Cambodia 1 month ago. A chest x-ray (CXR) shows reticulonodular opacities suggestive of active tuberculosis (TB). The student is curious about his likelihood of having active TB. He reads a study that compares sputum testing results between 2800 patients with likely active TB on the basis of history, clinical symptoms, and CXR pattern and 2400 controls. The results are shown:



Diagnosis of TB confirmed (sputum testing positive for TB)
Diagnosis of TB not confirmed (sputum testing negative for TB)
Total



Active TB suspected (based on history, clinical symptoms, and CXR pattern)
700
2100

300

5200



Which of the following is the likelihood that a patient with suspected active TB on the basis of history, clinical symptoms, and CXR pattern actually has active TB?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

1.4 is the positive likelihood ratio (LR+) of the clinical presentation that suggests active TB in this scenario. Positive likelihood ratio is the likelihood that an individual with a given condition will have a positive prediction (e.g., positive screening test or clinical presentation suggesting the condition) compared to the likelihood that an individual without the condition will have a positive prediction. LR+ is the true positive rate (TP rate) divided by the false positive rate (FP rate). This formula is expressed as LR+ = (TP rate)/(FP rate) = sensitivity/(1 - specificity). LR+ = 0.70 /(1 - 0.50) → 0.70/0.50 = 1.4.

B) CORRECT:

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that an individual with a certain test result or clinical presentation actually has the condition as confirmed by gold standard testing. PPV is calculated by dividing the number of true positives (TP) by the total number of positives, which includes both true and false positives (FP). This formula is expressed as PPV = TP/(TP + FP).

In this scenario, TP = 700 and FP = 2100. Therefore, PPV = 700/(700 + 2100) → 700/2800 = 0.25 or 25%.

PPV increases as the prevalence of a disease increases in a population.

C) INCORRECT:

0.50 is the specificity of the clinical presentation that suggests active TB in this scenario. Specificity is the number of true negatives (TN) divided by the combined number of false positives (FP) and true negatives. This formula is expressed as TN/(FP + TN). Specificity = 2100/(2100 + 2100) → 2100/4200 = 0.50 or 50%. Specificity is also known as the true negative rate because it expresses the probability that an individual without a condition will have a negative test result.

D) INCORRECT:

0.70 is the sensitivity of the clinical presentation that suggests active TB in this scenario. Sensitivity is the number of true positives (TP) divided by the combined total of false negatives (FN) and true positives (TP). This formula is expressed as TP/(FN + TP). Sensitivity = 700/(300 + 700) → 700/1000 = 0.70, or 70%. Sensitivity is also known as the true positive rate because it expresses the probability that an individual with a condition will have a positive test result.

E) INCORRECT:

0.88 is the negative predictive value (NPV) of the clinical presentation that suggests active TB in this scenario. NPV is the likelihood that an individual with a negative prediction of diagnosis actually does not have the condition. NPV is the number of true negatives (TN) divided by the combined number of true and false negatives (FN). This formula is expressed as NPV = TN/(FN + TN). NPV = 2100/(300 + 2100) → 2100/2400 = 0.88, or 88%
questions.hint: Positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that an individual with a certain test result or clinical presentation actually has the condition as confirmed by gold standard testing. In this scenario, a suspected diagnosis of active TB (based on history, clinical symptoms, and CXR pattern) is evaluated via sputum testing, which is the gold standard test.

A study is conducted to investigate the relationship between the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus and the use of atypical antipsychotic medications in patients with schizophrenia. 300 patients who received the atypical antipsychotic clozapine and 300 patients who received the typical antipsychotic haloperidol in long-acting injectable form were followed for 2 years. At the end of the observation period, the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus was compared between the two groups. Receipt of clozapine was found to be associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus relative to haloperidol (RR = 1.43, 95% p < 0.01).



Developed type 2 diabetes mellitus
Did not develop type 2 diabetes mellitus



Clozapine
30

Haloperidol
21

Based on these results, which of the following best represents the difference in the probability of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus in patients receiving clozapine and those taking a typical antipsychotic?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

33.3 is the number needed to harm (NNH), meaning the number of people that have to be exposed to the risk factor clozapine before one person develops diabetes mellitus. The NNH is calculated as one divided by the attributable risk: 1 / [(30/300) - (21/300)] = 1 / (0.1-0.07) ≈ 33.3.

B) INCORRECT:

0.3 is the attributable risk percent (ARP), not the attributable risk. The ARP is defined as the proportion of cases attributable to exposure to a risk factor, which can be easily calculated based on the relative risk (RR): ARP = (RR - 1) / RR. Since the relative risk of developing diabetes among those exposed to clozapine compared to those in the haloperidol group (not exposed) is (30/300) / (21/300) ≈ 1.43, the attributable risk percent is thus approximately (1.43-1) / 1.43 = 0.30, or 30%. This means that approximately 30% of type 2 diabetes mellitus cases in the clozapine group can be attributed to exposure to clozapine.

C) CORRECT:

0.03 is the attributable risk due to clozapine. Attributable risk is defined as the difference in disease occurrence attributable to an exposure. It is calculated as the cumulative incidence in the exposed group (clozapine group, 30/300 = 0.1) minus the cumulative incidence in the unexposed group (haloperidol group, 21/300 = 0.07): 0.1 - 0.07 = 0.03. This means that the absolute risk increase of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus attributable to clozapine is 3%.

D) INCORRECT:

1.48 is the odds ratio of developing diabetes among those exposed to clozapine (exposed) compared to those in the haloperidol group (unexposed), not the attributable risk. The odds ratio is calculated as the odds of disease in the exposed group divided by the odds of disease in the unexposed group. In this case: OR = (30/21) / (270/279) ≈ 1.48.

E) INCORRECT:

Those exposed to clozapine have a 43% increased risk of developing diabetes, given that the relative risk of developing diabetes in the clozapine group compared to the haloperidol group is 1.43. This is not equivalent, however, to the attributable risk of an exposure, which is calculated as the difference in risks rather than from the ratio of one risk to another.
questions.hint: The attributable risk is the excess risk in the clozapine group compared to the haloperidol group.

questions.text: An investigator conducts a study to determine whether earlier detection of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) in patients increases survival time. One subset of study participants consists of asymptomatic individuals who were diagnosed with GBM after undergoing a screening MRI of the brain. The other subset of study participants was diagnosed with GBM only after they developed symptoms. Results from the study show that the asymptomatic patients who were diagnosed with screening MRI had an average survival time that was 6 weeks longer than that of the patients who were diagnosed after symptom onset. Which of the following statistical biases is most likely to have occurred as a result of the endpoint selected for this study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selection bias is a collective term for a group of biases that occur when a sample population does not represent the general population from which the sample is drawn. There is no evidence of inappropriate sampling within the two groups selected for this experiment. Moreover, the use of the survival time as an endpoint for this screening study is more likely to result in a different bias.

B) INCORRECT:

Observer bias is a form of cognitive bias where prior knowledge or expectations of the investigator affect the group assignment of subjects. As the selection of patients was conducted based on patient family histories and clinical symptoms, it is unlikely that this bias occurred. Moreover, the use of the survival time as an endpoint for this screening study results in a different bias.

C) INCORRECT:

Some diseases are slowly progressive and will therefore be detectable by screening for longer periods of time than rapidly progressive diseases that are more likely to manifest clinically before being diagnosed by screening. Length-time bias refers to the overestimation of such slowly progressive disease cases, leading to the incorrect assumption that a screening test results in better outcomes or prognosis. A classic example is a cancer screening test that is assumed to improve outcomes but actually detects a higher number of asymptomatic, slow-growing tumors that would have been less dangerous or lethal irrespective of detection.

D) INCORRECT:

A confounding bias occurs when causality is established between the dependent (outcome) and independent variables (e.g., exposure to a risk factor), but the association is, in fact, due to a third variable that has not been factored into the study (the confounder). While confounding biases could have affected this study, the use of the survival time as an endpoint for this screening study results in a different bias.

E) INCORRECT:

Surveillance bias occurs when there is a higher probability of detecting an outcome in one exposed group than another, usually due to increased screening or diagnostic testing. In this case, only patients with the outcome are being studied, making surveillance bias irrelevant. The use of survival time as an endpoint in this study is more likely to result in a different type of bias.

F) CORRECT:

Lead-time bias occurs when the earlier detection of a disease (in this case, the diagnosis of GBM due to MRI screening) is misinterpreted as increased survival time and occurs in screening studies where survival times are used as endpoints. Earlier detection of a preexisting condition may only increase the time of awareness of the disease, but does not necessarily equate with a significant increase in actual survival time. A better endpoint measurement for screening tests is mortality rates between the screening groups, which minimizes this bias.
questions.hint: Studies of screening tests that use survival times as an endpoint are susceptible to this form of bias.

questions.text: The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This value is the number of all expected positive results of the new test (i.e., the sum of the true-positive results and false-positive results).

B) INCORRECT:

This value is the number of expected false-positive results of the new test, which is calculated as the number of people without malaria (i.e., 150, the number of people with a negative blood smear) multiplied by the false positive rate of the new test, which is defined as 1 – specificity. Thus, the number of expected false-positive results of the new test is 150 × (1 – 0.9) = 15.

C) INCORRECT:

This value is the number of all expected negative results of the new test (i.e., the sum of the true-negative results and false-negative results).

D) CORRECT:

The number of expected false-negative results of the new test is calculated as the number of people with malaria (i.e., 200, the number of people with a positive blood smear) multiplied by the false-negative rate of the new test, which is defined as 1 – sensitivity (true positive rate). Thus, the number of expected false-negative results of the new test is 200 × (1 – 0.7) = 60.

E) INCORRECT:

This value is the number of expected true-positive results of the new test, which is calculated as the number of people with malaria (i.e., 200, the number of people with a positive blood smear) multiplied by the sensitivity of the new test, which is given as 70%. Thus, the number of expected true positive results of the new test is 200 × 0.7 = 140.

This value is the number of expected true negative results of the new test, which is calculated as the number of people without malaria (i.e., 150, the number of people with a negative blood smear) multiplied by the specificity of the new test, which is given as 90%. questions.text: A multicenter study was performed with 5000 pregnant women to evaluate a new blood test for the prenatal diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Samples were taken at 30 weeks' gestation. 29 participants had positive tests. After birth, a sweat chloride test was obtained in all infants. Of the 29 pregnant women with abnormal blood test findings, 26 had babies with a positive sweat chloride test. Which of the following is required to calculate the specificity of this new blood test?

choices.text: Probability that a newborn whose mother had a positive blood test has cystic fibrosis
Incidence of cystic fibrosis in the general population
Number of mothers with a normal blood test whose newborns do not have cystic fibrosis
Prevalence of cystic fibrosis in the general population
Probability that a newborn has cystic fibrosis before the sweat chloride test is performed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This probability is also known as the positive predictive value (PPV). The formula for calculating PPV is PPV = True Positives/(True Positives + False Positives). In this scenario, the true and false positives are already known, and true negatives, which are the missing variable to calculate specificity, cannot be gleaned from the PPV alone. It would be possible to calculate true negatives in this scenario if the negative predictive value (NPV) was known because NPV = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Negatives), and the total number of patients who tested negative (i.e., True Negatives + False Negatives) is already known to be 4971.

B) INCORRECT:

The incidence of cystic fibrosis denotes the number of new cystic fibrosis cases within a specific time frame (e.g., one year). This parameter is not needed for the calculation of specificity.

C) CORRECT:

True negatives and false positives are necessary to calculate the specificity of this new blood test. False positives can be calculated from the data set (False Positives = Total Positives - True Positives; 29 - 26 = 3). True negatives, in this scenario, would be the number of pregnant women with normal blood tests in conjunction with newborns with a negative sweat chloride test.

D) INCORRECT:

The prevalence of cystic fibrosis denotes the number of total cystic fibrosis cases in the general population at a specific point in time. This parameter is not needed for the calculation of specificity.

If the prevalence of cystic fibrosis among newborns was known and the sample population is representative of newborns in the general population (i.e., no selection bias), it would be possible to calculate the total number of individuals with cystic fibrosis by multiplying the prevalence by the number of individuals in the study population (5000) and, subsequently, glean the total number of individuals in the study population without cystic fibrosis (i.e., False Positives + True Negatives). Since the False Positives are known in this scenario, the True Negatives, which is the missing variable for calculating specificity, could then be obtained. The prevalence of cystic fibrosis in the general population, however, is not equivalent to the prevalence of cystic fibrosis in newborns.

E) INCORRECT:

The probability that a patient with a particular manifestation has a specific disease before a diagnostic test is performed is called the pretest probability. Pretest probability is dependent upon disease prevalence in a particular region and is not needed to calculate specificity.
questions.hint: The specificity of a test is the probability that a given test is negative when the disease is absent. Specificity can be calculated using the formula Specificity = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives).

questions.text: A new rapid test for the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection is evaluated in 200 study participants. At a given cutoff, the test shows a true-negative rate of approximately 70% and a true-positive rate of approximately 65%. Which of the following labeled graphs is most likely to represent this diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This graph, which shows a ROC curve close to the left upper corner and an AUC almost equal to 1, represents the ideal diagnostic test with almost 100% sensitivity and specificity. In the test described above, with 65% sensitivity and 70% specificity, the ROC curve is not expected to be that close to the left upper corner.

B) CORRECT:

This graph represents a diagnostic test with sensitivity and specificity between 50% and 100%, corresponding to the described diagnostic test and an AUC > 0.5. A test with an AUC > 0.5 has diagnostic value because it can differentiate between individuals with and without disease with better accuracy than a test in which the result is randomly determined with a 50% chance for each outcome (e.g., a coin flip). The higher the AUC, the more accurate the test; the ideal diagnostic test has an AUC of 1.
Image Description:

The ROC curve illustrates the relationship between the sensitivity and specificity of a test.

The more closely the curve follows the Y axis, the more accurate the test. The more close the curve is to the diagonal dotted line (x = y), the less accurate the test.

When choosing a cutoff value, an upward shift on the ROC curve indicates increased sensitivity, and a shift to the right indicates decreased specificity.

C) INCORRECT:

This graph represents a diagnostic test that has an FP rate equal to the TP rate and an AUC of 0.5, indicating that the test performs just as well as a test in which the result is randomly determined with a 50% chance for each outcome (e.g., a coin flip). A test that detects the same number of true-positive and false-positive cases has no predictive diagnostic value.

D) INCORRECT:

This graph represents a diagnostic test that has an FP rate higher than the TP rate and an AUC < 0.5, indicating that the test performs worse than a test in which the result is randomly determined with a 50% chance for each outcome (e.g., a coin flip). Such a curve for a test usually indicates a mistake in plotting the data for the ROC.

E) INCORRECT:

This graph represents a diagnostic test that has an FP rate of almost 100%, a TP rate of almost 0%, and an AUC of 0, meaning that the test has no sensitivity or specificity for the diagnosis of the condition.

The curve that is obtained by plotting the true-positive rate (TP rate or sensitivity) against the FP rate is called a receiving operating characteristic (ROC) curve. The area under this curve (AUC) positively correlates with the diagnostic value of the test.

questions.text: A group of investigators conduct a study to evaluate a new test that uses targeted next-generation sequencing in order to rapidly diagnose tuberculosis. A total of 400 patients are enrolled in the study. Among them, 200 patients have no evidence of tuberculosis infection as determined by a culture of bronchoalveolar lavage specimens. The study shows that 180 patients with tuberculosis and 40 patients without tuberculosis have a positive result with the new test. Which of the following is the specificity of this new test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the false positive rate, which is calculated by dividing the number of false positives (healthy individuals with a positive test) by the total number of healthy individuals. In this study, there are 40 false positives and 200 healthy individuals; these figures yield a false positive rate of 20% (40/200).

B) CORRECT:

This is the specificity of the new test. Subtracting 40 (healthy individuals with a positive test) from 200 (total number of healthy individuals) yields 160, which is the number of true negatives (healthy individuals with a negative test). The number of true negatives is then divided by the total number of healthy individuals to yield a specificity of 0.80 or 80% (160/200). A highly specific test will have a low false-positive rate and can be used to confirm the diagnosis following a positive screening test.

C) INCORRECT:

This is the false negative rate, which is calculated by dividing the number of false negatives (diseased individuals with a negative test) by the total number of diseased individuals. In this study of the 400 individuals, 200 are healthy; so there are 200 diseased individuals. Of the 200 diseased individuals, 180 tested positive, so there are 20 false negatives. These figures yield a false negative rate of 10% (20/200).

D) INCORRECT:

This is the negative predictive value (NPV), which is calculated by dividing the number of true negatives (healthy individuals with a negative test) by the total number of negative tests (true negatives and false negatives). Of the 200 healthy individuals, 40 tested positive, so there are 160 true negatives. Of the 200 diseased individuals, 180 tested positive; so there are 20 false negatives (diseased individuals with a negative test). The total number of negative tests is 180 (160 + 20); these figures yield an NPV of approx. 89% (160/180).

E) INCORRECT:

This is the positive predictive value (PPV), which is calculated by dividing the number of true positives (diseased individuals with a positive test) by the total number of positive tests (true positives and false positives). In this study, there are 180 true positives and 220 positive tests (180 + 40); these figures yield a PPV of approximately 82% (180/220).

F) INCORRECT:

This is the sensitivity of the test, which is calculated by dividing the number of true positives (diseased individuals with a positive test) by the total number of diseased individuals. In this study, the number of true positives is 180. Of the 400 enrolled individuals, 200 are healthy; so the total number of diseased individuals is 200 (400 - 200). These figures yield a sensitivity of 90% (180/200).
questions.hint: Specificity (true negative rate) is calculated using the following formula: Specificity = TN/(FP+TN), where TN is the number of true negatives and FP is the number of false positives.

A) INCORRECT:

The likelihood that a patient with a disease will have a true positive test result is referred to as the sensitivity of a test (true positive rate). Sensitivity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by pretest probability.

B) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated from sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are unaffected by the pretest probability. Therefore, the positive likelihood ratio of the test will not change when it is tested in this patient compared to the trial setting.

C) CORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that an individual with a positive test result truly has the disease, i.e., true positives/(true positives + false positives). PPV is directly related to pretest probability; PPV decreases as pretest probability decrease. Similarly, a decrease in prevalence results in a lower pretest probability and, therefore, a decrease in PPV. The study population prevalence of HEV infection in this scenario is 25/145 = 17%, which is certainly much higher than the prevalence of Hepatitis E for the general population. Negative predictive value (NPV) is inversely related to pretest probability; NPV increases as pretest probability decreases.

Pretest probability does not influence intrinsic test characteristics, i.e., sensitivity, specificity, negative likelihood ratio, and positive likelihood ratio.

D) INCORRECT:

The likelihood that a patient with a negative test truly does not have the disease is the negative predictive value (NPV). The NPV would increase, not decrease, because the pretest probability of HEV infection is lower in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Precision (i.e., reliability) is the reproducibility of test results on the same sample under similar conditions. Therefore, precision can only be calculated from data obtained in a consistent setting (e.g., test results from groups of trial participants) and is not applicable to the performance of a test in a single individual.
questions.hint: The patient is asymptomatic and presenting to an office, whereas the study participants were drawn from a population of patients with symptoms of hepatitis presenting to an emergency department. Therefore, this patient has a lower pretest probability of HEV infection than the trial group.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressively worsening cough for the past 3 weeks. His mother reports that the coughs occur in bouts and are occasionally followed by vomiting. One week ago, he was prescribed amoxicillin, but his cough has continued to worsen. Immunization records are not available. His two cousins, with whom he spent Thanksgiving, have similar symptoms. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mmHg. A new rapid test to confirm pertussis has a sensitivity of 10% and a specificity of 90%. Based on this information, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the test?

choices.text: The test is not useful to confirm pertussis.
There is a 10% probability that a patient with a positive test has pertussis.
There is a 50% probability that a patient with a negative test does not have pertussis.
There is a 10% probability that a patient with pertussis has a negative test.
There is not enough information to determine the diagnostic value of the test.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Generally, a test with a high specificity can be used to rule in a disease. However, a test with high specificity but very low sensitivity has a poor diagnostic value. For such a test, the positive likelihood ratio (LR+), which is sensitivity/(1 - specificity), should be determined first. In this scenario, LR+ is 10%/(100% - 90%) = 1, indicating that patients without pertussis are just as likely to have a positive test as patients with pertussis.

Similarly, a disease cannot effectively be ruled out using a test with a high sensitivity but very low specificity. For such a test, the negative likelihood ratio (LR-), which is (1 - sensitivity)/specificity, should be determined first. In this scenario, LR- is (100% - 10%)/90% = 1, indicating that patients with pertussis are just as likely to have a negative test as patients without pertussis.

This test with an LR+ and LR- of 1 has no clinical utility. A test with an LR+ > 10 is highly effective at ruling in a disease. An LR- < 0.1 indicates that a test is highly effective at ruling out a disease.

B) INCORRECT:

The probability that a patient with a positive test has pertussis is the positive predictive value (PPV), which cannot be estimated because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. PPV should not be confused with sensitivity, the probability of a patient with pertussis having a positive test.

C) INCORRECT:

The probability that a patient with a negative test does not have pertussis is the negative predictive value (NPV), which cannot be estimated because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. Given the sensitivity and specificity in this scenario, an NPV of 50% can only be obtained by assuming a 50% pretest probability of pertussis (e.g., a sample of 200 patients, of whom 100 have pertussis and 100 do not).

D) INCORRECT:

The probability that a patient with pertussis has a negative test is the false negative rate, which is equal to 1 - sensitivity. The false negative rate in this scenario is 100% - 10% = 90%.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient information to determine post-test probabilities (e.g., negative predictive value, positive predictive value) because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. However, the test's sensitivity and specificity are sufficient to determine the diagnostic value of the test.
questions.hint: Likelihood ratios, which are calculated from sensitivity and specificity, can be used to determine the utility of a diagnostic test. A likelihood ratio compares the probability of a test result in an individual with the disease to the probability of the same result in an individual without the disease.

Methods
Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial (Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study). ClinicalTrials.gov FJIM 11001110.
Allocation: Concealed.
Blinding: Double-blinded.
Follow-up period: Up to 5 years.

A 68-year-old man with a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. One week ago, he had an ophthalmologist appointment during which he underwent repeat laser photocoagulation for severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. Medical history is also notable for diabetic chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and a stroke 3 years ago. He feels well. Current medications include metformin, empagliflozin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Pulse is 79/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/83 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show an HbA1c of 6.8%, which is at target, and an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m2. Urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 30 mg/g. The patient is a retired military physician who is following recent developments in the pharmaceutical market. He considers a switch from empagliflozin to ambogliflozin therapy. Based on the abstract shown, informing this patient of which of the following effects of the new treatment on his condition is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The most common adverse effects (AEs) of SGLT-2 inhibitors include urinary and genital tract infections, dehydration, weight loss, orthostatic hypotension, and severe diabetic ketoacidosis. However, the incidence of these AEs was not assessed in the study. The only AE assessed was hypoglycemia, and the difference in incidence between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant (i.e., 95% confidence interval of the relative risk includes the null value 1). Other assessed outcomes are more likely to be complications of diabetes than AEs of treatment with an antidiabetic drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the study reports a lower incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy, this patient already has DR. Progression of preexisting DR was not an outcome measure of the study and the potential impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of DR cannot be drawn from the results.

C) CORRECT:

Statistical significance does not necessarily result in clinical significance. In the study, mean change in eGFR over time was statistically significantly higher (p < 0.001) in the ambogliflozin group (+2.3 ± 0.2 mL/min/1.73 m2) than in those who received standard combination therapy (-0.5 ± 0.3 mL/min/1.73 m2). However, while this patient has chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m2 (stage G3 according to the classification of CKD), an increase in eGFR of 2.3 mL/min/1.73 m2 would most likely have no clinically significant benefit on his individual health outcomes. The only other statistically significant result of the trial is decreased incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group compared to those who received standard combination therapy. However, this patient already has DR and further studies would be needed to evaluate the impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of preexisting DR.

D) INCORRECT:

The main results of the clinical trial show that patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy had an average BMI reduction of -3 ± 1 kg/m2 over the study period vs. -1 ± 3 kg/m2 in those who received standard combination therapy. However, this difference was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.5) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's diabetes is already well-controlled at target HbA1c values. Additionally, in the study, the difference in HbA1c levels over time between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.1) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.
questions.hint: When applying study results to patient care, individual patient history should be taken into account to weigh up the most likely benefits and risks.

Which of the following most strongly limits the generalizability of the findings in the study?

choices.text: The statistician performing the analysis was blinded
Patient selection was not representative of the general patient population
A large number of patients were lost to follow-up
The treatment of chronic kidney disease is limited to quaternary care centers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In double-blinded clinical trials, neither the participants nor the researchers know who is in the control group and who is in the treatment group. However, the statistician performing the analysis would not be blinded. The statistician would be blinded in a triple-blinded trial design. In addition, blinding generally reduces biases and increases internal validity in randomized controlled trials, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

B) INCORRECT:

Allocation concealment (blind randomization) is a method used in randomized clinical trials to prevent selection bias. Participants are randomly assigned to either the treatment or the control group using techniques such as centralized randomization schemes and sequentially numbered containers. Concealed allocation is a quality criterion in randomized controlled trials and increases validity, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

C) CORRECT:

Generalizability (external validity) is the applicability of study results to populations other than the study population. A study must be internally valid to have external validity. However, high internal validity does not guarantee external validity. A lack of external validity can arise, for example, if the study population is not representative of the patient population as a whole. This study only included patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes with HbA1c ≤ 8.5% who did not have concomitant diabetic neuropathy or previous kidney transplant. In addition, the study population consisted only of veterans, and 95% of the participants were men. The study population is therefore unlikely to represent the patient population with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease as a whole, which strongly limits generalizability.

D) INCORRECT:

Loss to follow-up can result in attrition bias and can have a significant impact on the internal validity of a study, also limiting its generalizability. However, in this study, only 2% of patients were lost to follow-up.

E) INCORRECT:

The level of care is an indicator of the complexity of medical cases treated. Some therapeutic interventions (e.g., experimental procedures, robot surgery) are only available at quarternary care centers because they must be performed by specialists who only practice in quarternary care centers. Studies using such interventions have limited generalizability because the treatment is often not accessible to the majority of patients. However, chronic kidney disease is a common long-term comorbidity of type 2 diabetes and can be treated by physicians practicing at secondary and tertiary care centers, and SGLT-2 inhibitors are widely available.
questions.hint: To assess whether a study is generalizable, the study population characteristics and set-up of the trial have to be evaluated.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 20% reduced risk of developing hypoglycemia compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing hypoglycemia was 2% lower in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy than in those who received standard combination therapy (10% vs. 12%, respectively).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a relative risk of developing cardiovascular complications of 0.9 compared to patients who received standard combination therapy. This means that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 10% reduced risk of developing cardiovascular complications compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing cardiovascular complications, on the other hand, was 1% lower in patients in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy (12% vs. 13%, respectively).

C) INCORRECT:

There was no statistically significant difference in mean body mass index (BMI) reduction between the two groups (p-value > alpha level). Additionally, the table reports the crude variation in BMI over time, not the likelihood of losing weight in one arm vs. the other arm of the trial. In order to obtain this information, the investigators would need to fit a linear regression model investigating the association between ambogliflozin combination therapy and BMI reduction over time.

In this study, the incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) has a relative risk (RR) of 0.6 in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy compared to standard combination therapy. The confidence interval does not include the null value of 1 and the results are therefore statistically significant. When results of a study are presented as RR, the corresponding relative risk reduction (if RR < 1) is calculated as follows: % risk reduction = (1 - RR) x 100; relative risk increase (if RR > 1) is calculated as follows: % risk increase = (RR - 1) x 100. In this study, relative risk reduction is (1 - 0.6) x 100 = 40%.

Relative risk reduction should not be confused with absolute risk reduction (ARR), which is calculated as follows: ARR = risk in control group - risk in treatment group. In this study, the ARR for DR would be 12% - 7% = 5%. The risk of developing DR in the ambogliflozin group is therefore 5% lower than the risk of developing DR in the standard combination therapy group.
questions.hint: The outcomes of this study are reported as mean change ± 2 SD with corresponding p-values, and incidence with corresponding relative risk and 95% confidence interval.
