This formula calculates the negative likelihood ratio (LR-), which measures the diagnostic utility of a test. LR- is the likelihood of an individual who has the disease testing negative divided by the likelihood of an individual who does not have the disease testing negative. LR- is calculated as (1 - sensitivity)/specificity.

B) INCORRECT:

This formula calculates the false positive rate (FPR) of the test, which is 1 - specificity. Because the specificity of a test is its true negative rate, the FPR in this scenario is calculated as 1 - 0.96 = 0.04. The FPR of a test can also be calculated as the proportion of false positives to the total number of patients without the disease or FP/(FP + TN). The FPR in this scenario is calculated as 4/(4 + 94) = 4/98 = 0.04.

C) CORRECT:

In this scenario, the test's NPV is the likelihood that a patient with a negative test for H. pylori infection truly does not have the disease. The FNR in this scenario is calculated as 55/(495 + 55) = 55/550 = 0.1.

Based on this information, a negative result of which of the following tests decreases the likelihood of having the infection most?

A) INCORRECT:

Test A, which has a high specificity and a positive likelihood ratio of 0.7/(1 - 0.9) = 7, can be used to confirm (rule in) the diagnosis but has a low sensitivity and a negative likelihood ratio of (1 - 0.7)/0.9 = 0.33. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Test B has a low sensitivity and a negative likelihood ratio of (1 - 0.75)/0.75 = 0.33. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Generally, a test with high sensitivity can be used to rule out disease but a test with high sensitivity and very low specificity has poor clinical utility. The negative likelihood ratio is a better test characteristic to compare the ability of tests with similar sensitivity to rule out a disease. The negative likelihood ratio of this test is (1 - 0.9)/0.4 = 0.25. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.

D) CORRECT:

The likelihood ratio (LR) represents the probability of a positive or negative test result in someone with the disease of interest over the probability of the test result in someone without the disease. LRs reflect how much more likely a disease is in a person with a given test result compared to their pretest probability. The lower the value of the negative likelihood ratio (i.e., the closer to 0 it is), the larger the effect of a negative test result in reducing the post-test probability of disease. LR- is calculated using the equation (1 - sensitivity)/specificity. In this scenario, the LR- of Test D is (1 - 0.85)/0.9 = 0.17, which is the lowest LR- of the four tests. LR- < 0.1 indicates that the test is effective at ruling out the presence of disease.

Similarly, a high positive likelihood ratio (LR+) indicates that a positive test strongly increases the post-test probability of disease. LR+ is calculated using the equation sensitivity/(1 - specificity). An LR+ > 10 indicates that the test is highly effective at ruling in a disease.

A 30-year-old man presents for evaluation of low back pain that has persisted for several months. You are considering a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis and recall that a genetic test for HLA-B27 may be helpful in diagnosing this condition. You obtain a family history, which is negative for ankylosing spondylitis, and the patient reports predominantly European ancestry.
Consulting a reference, you find that (a) 90% of men of European ancestry with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, and (b) 10% of healthy men of European ancestry (i.e., without ankylosing spondylitis) are HLA-B27 positive.
Given this patient’s history and physical examination, you estimate that the patient’s probability of having ankylosing spondylitis (the pretest probability) is 10%.
Which one of the following values represents the positive predictive value of HLA-B27 for ankylosing spondylitis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sensitivity and specificity of HLA-B27 testing in this population are both 90%. The positive predictive value is not the same as either sensitivity or specificity.

B) INCORRECT:

The calculated positive predictive value in this scenario is not 75%.

C) CORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a patient with a positive test result actually has the disease. To calculate PPV, one must know the sensitivity and specificity of the test as well as the patient’s probability of having the disease of interest (the pretest probability). In this case, we are interested in HLA-B27 testing for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) among men of European ancestry:

• The sensitivity of HLA-B27 in this population is 90% (90% of men of European ancestry with AS are HLA-B27 positive).
• The specificity is also 90% (90% of men of European ancestry without AS will be HLA-B27 negative, given that 10% will be HLA-B27 positive).
• The pretest probability, as estimated by the clinician, is 10%.

The easiest way to calculate PPV is to construct a 2 x 2 table. In a hypothetical population of 100 back-pain patients with a 10% pretest probability of AS, 10 will have AS, and 9 of them will be HLA-B27 positive (90% sensitivity). Conversely, 90 patients will not have AS, and 81 of them will be HLA-B27 negative (90% specificity). The corresponding 2 x 2 table is shown below.

The table shows that only 9 of the 18 patients who are HLA-B27 positive actually have the disease; thus, the positive predictive value is 50%. Stated another way, even if this patient tests positive for HLA-B27, his probability of having AS is still only 50%. HLA-B27 testing is most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of AS in patients whose pretest probability is relatively high, based on certain findings in the history (e.g., pain and stiffness that improves with activity), physical examination (e.g., limited motion of the spine), and imaging (e.g., sacroiliitis).

Key learning point: In order to calculate a test’s positive predictive value (the proportion of test-positive people who actually have the disease), one must know sensitivity, specificity, and pretest probability (the background prevalence of the disease in the population that is being tested).

D) INCORRECT:

The pretest probability, as estimated by the clinician, is 10%. The positive predictive value is a posttest probability and has a different value.

E) INCORRECT:

The calculated positive predictive value in this scenario is not 25%.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents in the winter with fever, runny nose, cough, and bilateral leg pain for the past 2 days. A point-of-care rapid influenza test, which has a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 98%, is positive for influenza infection.
What additional information would be most helpful in determining the probability that this patient has influenza?

choices.text: The proportion of women aged 25 to 35 with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive rapid-test result
The lifetime incidence of influenza among all women in the patient’s community
The prevalence of influenza among women aged 25 to 35 in the patient’s community who had an upper respiratory infection during the past month
The incidence of influenza among women aged 25 to 35 in the patient’s community during the past winter
The proportion of women aged 25 to 35 without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive rapid-test result

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of women with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-negative result on the rapid test, but it does not help to define a pretest probability.

B) INCORRECT:

The lifetime incidence of influenza in this case would be the proportion of women in the community who were ever diagnosed with influenza, no matter the age at diagnosis. This information would not provide the best pretest probability of influenza for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

All screening and diagnostic tests have two intrinsic test characteristics: sensitivity (the proportion of patients with the condition who test positive) and specificity (the proportion of patients without the condition who test negative). However, a more useful concept for clinicians who are interpreting diagnostic tests are the positive predictive value (PPV), which is the probability that an individual who tests positive actually has the condition, and the negative predictive value (NPV), which is the probability that an individual who tests negative does not have the condition. In this particular scenario, the PPV is the proportion of all women aged 25 to 35 with an upper respiratory infection (URI) and a positive rapid-test result who actually have influenza infection, as determined on a gold-standard test (polymerase-chain-reaction assay or viral culture).

The PPV and NPV depend on both the intrinsic characteristics of the test and the pretest probability that the patient has the condition of interest. The pretest probability is best approximated from the prevalence of the condition in a population similar to that of the patient in question. Therefore, the additional information that would be most helpful in determining whether this patient truly has influenza is the prevalence of influenza among women aged 25 to 35 in her community who had URI symptoms in the past month. Using the same diagnostic test (with a given sensitivity and specificity) in a population with higher disease prevalence increases the PPV; that is, someone who tests positive is more likely to have true disease. Conversely, increased prevalence results in decreased NPV; individuals who test negative are more likely to actually have disease. Therefore, when considering predictive values of diagnostic tests, it is important to take into account the influence of the prevalence of disease.

See “Features of a two-by-two table summarizing screening or diagnostic test results” table.

Key learning point: The pretest probability that a patient has a given condition is best estimated by the prevalence of that condition in a population similar to that of the patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Incidence is defined as the rate at which a condition occurs in a population. For example, if influenza diagnoses among women in a particular community accrue at a rate of 3% per person-month during the winter, then the women in that community have a 3% chance each month of being diagnosed with influenza. Incidence does not define the pretest probability for an individual patient at the time a test is administered.

E) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of women without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative result on the rapid test provides information about the specificity of the test but, again, does not help to define a pretest probability.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with moderately severe asthma presents for follow-up. Despite adherence to therapy with an inhaled glucocorticoid and long-acting beta-agonist, she continues to have multiple severe exacerbations requiring hospitalization and systemic glucocorticoid use. You are considering initiation of a novel biologic therapy; however, when you discuss this with the patient, she mentions a family member who suffered a severe rash with this drug.
The drug product monograph notes that severe skin reactions have been reported since the drug was approved, affecting an estimated 1% of patients who receive the drug. You review the primary phase 3 research study, which demonstrated the drug’s efficacy in severe asthma, and note that the researchers enrolled 100 patients in the active-drug arm and another 100 patients to the placebo arm.
What is the probability that at least one severe rash was observed in this study?

choices.text: The probability of detection cannot be determined because adverse events occur randomly

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 0%.

B) INCORRECT:

While it is true that adverse events occur randomly, the probability of detecting an adverse event can be estimated using statistical methods.

C) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 100%.

D) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 10%.

E) CORRECT:

Clinical trials are routinely powered with the intention of identifying differences in clinical outcomes between study groups if differences exist. Adverse events from therapeutic interventions must also be reported in these studies; however, rare adverse reactions may be detected only if there are enough study participants to experience them. Therefore, many rare adverse events are reported only in postmarketing studies, when large numbers of patients have been exposed to the therapy in question.

As a general rule, a research team would have to administer a drug to three times as many participants as the frequency of the event to detect that event with 95% confidence. Therefore, if the adverse event occurred in 1 in 100 people (1%), one would need to give the drug to roughly 300 people in order for there to be a 95% likelihood of detecting one event. A more specific formula for the probability of detecting the event is:

1 - (1 - probability of event)number of study participants

To see how to apply this formula in this problem, we note that the probability of the event is 0.01 (1%) and the number of study participants is 100. Plugging those numbers into the formula, we get:

P(at least 1 adverse event) = 1 - (1 - 0.01)100 = 1 - 0.99100 = 1 - 0.366 = 0.634

Therefore, in our example with an adverse reaction occurring in 1% of patients, a study that enrolled 100 patients in the active treatment arm would have a 63% probability of detecting the reaction.

Key learning point: If an adverse drug reaction occurs in 1% of patients, the probability of detecting it in a study with 100 patients receiving the drug is 63%

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman reports that her previously healthy father was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. She has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens.
She has read multiple media reports about exposures to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks you about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A (BPA) in the plastic containers that she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her children. You decide to review the literature in an attempt to answer her question.
Which one of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-sectional studies are a type of observational study in which population-level data are analyzed at a single point in time. Because of the descriptive nature of these studies, they cannot be used to estimate the risk difference or determine the temporal relationship between the exposure and the outcome.

B) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

C) CORRECT:

The study design that is best suited to investigate the link between environmental exposures and rare outcomes is a cohort study. In prospective cohort studies, groups of patients who do and do not have the exposure in question are followed to determine if they develop a defined outcome. This type of study provides a direct measure of risk difference (incidence in the exposed group minus incidence in the unexposed group). In this example, the exposed cohort would be those who had exposure to bisphenol A (BPA), and the outcome would be the development of pancreatic cancer.

An alternative way to address this question would be a case-control study. In this type of study, researchers enroll individuals who already have or do not have the outcome in question (in this case, pancreatic cancer). These individuals are then studied retrospectively to determine their exposures. This study design is subject to recall bias, which can limit the strength of the conclusions drawn.

Key learning point: The two study designs best suited to assess whether an environmental exposure may be causing a rare outcome are cohort studies and case-control studies.

D) INCORRECT:

A case series is a type of descriptive study that is used to report rare or novel associations between an exposure and an outcome. This type of study is useful for documenting rare clinical events but cannot provide analytical measures such as risk difference.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical. This same limitation applies to crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents for routine care 6 weeks after giving birth to her first child. She lives with her partner, who is a smoker. She asks you about the health effects of household smoking on children, especially on the risk of developing childhood asthma.
In your literature search, you find an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma.
Which one of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?

choices.text: Increase the follow-up time of the study
Adjust the analysis for sex, socioeconomic class, and exposure to air pollution
Change the study design to a randomized controlled trial
Increase the sample size of the study

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although increasing the follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how long participants were followed.

B) INCORRECT:

Adjustment for multiplicity is an approach to handle performing many statistical tests in a single analysis, but it does not address confounding.

C) CORRECT:

Confounders are factors that affect both the exposure and the outcome in a study. For example, in this study, a possible confounder is air pollution, which could be associated with both household tobacco smoke (the exposure of interest) and the development of childhood asthma (the outcome of interest). If this confounder is not properly accounted for, then the observed association between household tobacco smoke and childhood asthma could be incorrectly interpreted to signify causation. Researchers can address and reduce confounding during study design, analysis, or both.

One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios where RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children. In observational studies, the effects of confounding can be minimized during study design by restricting the inclusion criteria so that the study population is homogenous with respect to a particular variable — for example, by including only a certain socioeconomic class.

Because confounders are prevalent in observational studies, they should also be adjusted for in the analysis. Multivariable regression models and propensity score methods can be used to do this. Multivariable regression models include the confounders in the model for the outcome and allow estimation of the association between the exposure and the outcome, controlling for the confounders. Propensity score methods estimate the probability of exposure and then estimate the group difference using the propensity score. Approaches to using the propensity score include matching on the propensity score, controlling for or stratifying on the propensity score, and inverse probability weighting using a function of the propensity score.

Key learning point: Confounders are factors that can introduce bias in a study by affecting both the exposure and the outcome.

D) INCORRECT:

One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios where RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children. In observational studies, the effects of confounding can be minimized during study design by restricting the inclusion criteria so that the study population is homogenous with respect to a particular variable — for example, by including only a certain socioeconomic class.

E) INCORRECT:

Although increasing the sample size of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and you are now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. You review the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in adults with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival.
What is the main question that this study was designed to address?

choices.text: What is the best chemotherapy agent for patients with Ph+ ALL?
Do patients with Ph+ ALL live longer if they are treated with the new chemotherapy agent?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent, compared with standard care, on progression-free survival in adults with Ph+ ALL?
Is the new chemotherapy agent better than standard care at improving progression-free survival in patients with ALL?
What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent on progression-free survival in adults with ALL?

questions.text:
You and your colleagues are discussing your clinic’s choice of influenza vaccine for the upcoming influenza season. You note that a new influenza vaccine was recently tested in a randomized controlled trial. The trial showed that 2% of participants receiving the new vaccine developed laboratory-confirmed influenza infection (the primary outcome) compared with 3% of those receiving the standard vaccine. You describe these results to your colleagues by stating that “the number needed to treat was 100.”
What does your statement mean in this context?

choices.text: If we treated 100 participants with the new vaccine, one additional participant would be immune against influenza
For every 100 cases of laboratory-confirmed influenza occurring in patients treated with the old vaccine, one case could have been prevented if they had received the new vaccine
If we treated 100 patients with the new vaccine, one additional participant would develop laboratory-confirmed influenza
The new vaccine would need to be given to at least 100 people for the trial results to be valid
If we treated 100 patients with the new vaccine rather than the old vaccine, we would prevent one additional case of laboratory-confirmed influenza

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The endpoint, in this case, is not a guarantee of immunity against influenza but rather the prevention of one more case of laboratory-confirmed influenza. Moreover, the number needed to treat (NNT) must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

B) INCORRECT:

The correct interpretation of the number needed to treat (NNT) in this study is that if we treated 100 patients with the new vaccine rather than the old vaccine, we would prevent one case of laboratory-confirmed influenza.

C) INCORRECT:

An implication of harm (developing laboratory-confirmed influenza) is not supported by the provided data. Harm from intervention in comparison to control is measured by the number needed to harm (NNH), not the number needed to treat (NNT). Moreover, the number needed to treat (NNT) must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

D) INCORRECT:

The number needed to treat (NNT) is not a measure of trial validity.

E) CORRECT:

The number needed to treat (NNT) is a measure of the clinical effect of a particular intervention compared with another intervention or a control. It is calculated by taking the reciprocal of the absolute risk difference between groups. In this example, 2% of participants receiving the new vaccine developed the primary outcome compared with 3% of participants receiving the standard vaccine. This provides an absolute risk difference of 0.01 (3/100 - 2/100). The reciprocal of 0.01 (1/0.01) is 100, which is the number needed to treat.

The NNT tells us the number of participants, on average, who need to receive a given intervention in order to prevent one more adverse outcome than would have occurred in the control setting. In other words, in this study, if we treated 100 patients with the new vaccine rather than the old vaccine, we would prevent one case of laboratory-confirmed influenza.

NNT is often considered to be a more intuitive measure for clinical decision-making than a relative risk or odds ratio is. It is especially useful in cases of a single intervention with a definitive end point, such as confirmed disease or death. Of note, it must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

Key learning point: The number needed to treat is the number of participants, on average, who need to receive a given intervention in order to prevent one more adverse outcome than would have occurred in the control setting.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports that she has been regularly using tanning beds but is nervous about it after seeing a news story that they increase the risk of skin cancer. She shows you the story and asks for your opinion.
You find the paper referenced in the story. It describes a prospective cohort study conducted among 600 women aged ≥30 years: 300 who reported current regular use of tanning beds and 300 who did not. During the 10-year study period, the women completed annual surveys indicating whether they had been diagnosed with skin cancer in the preceding year. At the end of the 10-year period, researchers reported that the relative risk of skin cancer associated with tanning-bed use was 1.63 (95% confidence interval, 1.13–2.36).
How can we interpret the estimated risk ratio from this study?

choices.text: Study participants who used tanning beds had a 63% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
Study participants who used tanning beds were 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer than those who did not use tanning beds
Study participants who used tanning beds had a 163% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
63% of study participants who used tanning beds developed skin cancer
There was an average of 1.63 more skin-cancer diagnoses per year in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A risk ratio (also known as relative risk) estimates the relationship between an exposure and an outcome of interest. It is calculated by determining the risk in the exposed group and dividing it by the risk in the unexposed group. The data from this type of study can be shown in a 2 x 2 table: See “Two-by-two table”.

Using the values from the table, we can calculate the risk in each group:
• Risk in the exposed group = (number with the event among the exposed) / (total number exposed) = a / (a + b)
• Risk in the unexposed group = (number with the event among the unexposed) / (total number unexposed) = c / (c + d)

The risk ratio can then be calculated as follows:
• Risk ratio = [a / (a + b)] / [c / (c + d)]

A risk ratio of 1 means that the event is equally likely to occur in the exposed and unexposed groups. A risk ratio >1 means that the event is more likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. A risk ratio <1 means the event is less likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group.

In this study, which had 300 participants in each group, the 2 x 2 table might look like the one shown below.
The risk of skin cancer in tanning-bed users is 62/300 = 0.2067
The risk of skin cancer in nonusers is 38/300 = 0.1267
The risk ratio is 0.2067/0.1267 = 1.63

This risk ratio can be described in a few different ways:
• The risk of developing skin cancer is increased by 63% in the tanning-bed users
• There is a 63% increased risk of skin cancer in tanning-bed users compared with nonusers
• Tanning-bed use is associated with a 63% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer
• Tanning-bed users are 1.63 times more likely to develop skin cancer than nonusers
The risk ratio does not tell us the percentage of tanning-bed users who develop skin cancer (that would be the risk in the exposed; 21% in this study) or the absolute change in risk from tanning-bed use (that would be the risk difference). The risk difference for this case is 0.2067 - 0.1267 = 0.08.

Of note, such a high incidence of skin cancer is unlikely to be seen in a real-life study unless the study population was selected for individuals at high risk, such as patients taking certain immunosuppressive regimens.

Key learning point: Relative risk is the ratio of the risk of an outcome in an exposed group compared with the risk in an unexposed group.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk ratio of 1.63 does not mean that tanning-bed users are 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer. Rather, it means they are 1.63 times more likely, or have a 63% increased risk, compared with nonusers.

C) INCORRECT:

The absolute change in risk from tanning-bed use (that would be the risk difference) is 0.2067 - 0.1267 = 0.08 = 8%.

D) INCORRECT:

The risk ratio does not tell us the percentage of tanning-bed users who develop skin cancer (that would be the risk in the exposed; 21% in this study).

E) INCORRECT:

There was an average of 1.63 more skin-cancer diagnoses per 10-year study period (not in 1 year) in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not.

Of the 242 patients with positive results, 228 had influenza confirmed on a gold-standard test. Of the 278 patients with negative results, 266 did not have influenza on gold-standard testing.
The 2x2 table below is drawn for these results.

What is the positive likelihood ratio in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated using the formula +LR = sensitivity / (1 - specificity). Based on the 2x2 table provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 33.

B) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated using the formula +LR = sensitivity / (1 - specificity). Based on the 2x2 table provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 0.86.

C) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated using the formula +LR = sensitivity / (1 - specificity) while the negative likelihood ratio is calculated using the formula -LR = (1 - sensitivity) / specificity. Based on the 2x2 table provided in this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95. Given these values, 0.05 represents the negative likelihood ratio: -LR = (1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05.

D) INCORRECT:

In this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95. Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of the test itself. Sensitivity refers to the proportion of patients with the disease of interest who test positive; it is a measure of how good the test is at identifying true positives. Specificity refers to the proportion of patients without the disease of interest who test negative; it is a measure of how good the test is at identifying true negatives.

E) CORRECT:

Clinical practice often involves interpreting diagnostic test results, and this requires an understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of a given test. Several measures can be used to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a test, including sensitivity and specificity, positive and negative predictive values, and likelihood ratios.

Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of the test itself. Sensitivity refers to the proportion of patients with the disease of interest who test positive; it is a measure of how good the test is at identifying true positives. Specificity, on the other hand, refers to the proportion of patients without the disease of interest who test negative; it is a measure of how good the test is at identifying true negatives. Although sensitivity and specificity are useful, they do not help clinicians understand the significance of a patient’s positive or negative test result. This information is provided by the positive and negative predictive values.

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the proportion of patients with a positive test result who actually have the disease of interest; the negative predictive value (NPV) is the proportion of patients with a negative test result who do not have the disease. Although the PPV and NPV depend on the inherent performance of the test (the specificity and sensitivity), they are also highly dependent on the prevalence of disease in the population being tested. For this reason, the same test will have a lower PPV in a low-prevalence situation than in a high-prevalence situation. For example, a positive test result for influenza is more likely to be a true positive in winter — when the PPV is higher — than in summer.

To avoid having to account for prevalence, one can instead calculate positive and negative likelihood ratios.

Likelihood ratios are calculated using sensitivity and specificity and can express the relationship between these two measures in a single figure, which in turn can be used to adjust the pretest probability of disease.

A positive likelihood ratio compares the probability of a person with the disease of interest testing positive to the probability of a person without the disease testing positive. It can be calculated as follows:

+LR = sensitivity / (1 - specificity)

A positive likelihood ratio of 1 means that the test has no predictive value. The higher the positive likelihood ratio (i.e., the further away from 1 it is), the more informative and useful the test. Values greater than 10 are considered to have a high effect on increasing the post-test probability of disease.

A negative likelihood ratio compares the probability of a person without the disease of interest testing negative to the probability of a person with the disease testing negative. It can be calculated as follows:

-LR = (1 - sensitivity) / specificity

The lower the value of the negative likelihood ratio (i.e., the closer to 0 it is), the larger the effect of a negative test result in reducing the post-test likelihood of disease; negative likelihood ratios below 0.1 are considered to have a large effect on the post-test probability of disease.

Based on the 2x2 table provided in this scenario, the test characteristics of the at-home influenza test can be calculated as shown in the table below. Given these values, the likelihood ratios can be calculated as follows:

+LR = 0.95/(1–0.95) = 19

-LR = (1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05

The positive likelihood ratio is high (>10), indicating that the new at-home test is likely to be useful in diagnosing the presence of influenza. The negative likelihood ratio is low (<0.1), indicating that a negative test is good at ruling out the presence of disease. Together, these ratios suggest that the test performs well in accurately detecting the presence of disease.

Key learning point: A positive likelihood ratio compares the probability of a person with the disease of interest testing positive to the probability of a person without the disease testing positive.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with five confirmed episodes of urinary tract infection (UTI) in the past 12 months presents with current symptoms of dysuria and increased frequency of urination. Urinalysis and urine culture are consistent with a UTI. The patient asks you about antibiotic prophylaxis.
In reviewing the literature, you find a randomized controlled trial on the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent recurrent UTIs in menopausal women.
Which one of the following statements about this study’s design is true?

choices.text: The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections.
The study design ensures that even adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all women with recurrent urinary tract infections.
This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The statistical analyses used for clinical trials are similar to those used in other study designs. Randomization in a clinical trial allows estimation of the causal effect, but the statistical approaches used are not different in this study design than in others.

B) INCORRECT:

The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.

C) INCORRECT:

RCTs are not feasible for rare disorders, because it is difficult to recruit enough patients that meet the enrollment criteria. Similarly, although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all women with recurrent urinary tract infection, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants. RCTs are not feasible for rare disorders, because it is difficult to recruit enough patients that meet the enrollment criteria. Similarly, although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

E) CORRECT:

The primary advantage of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections.

Key learning point: The main advantage of a randomized controlled trial design, despite its compromise of external generalizability, is high internal validity to permit inference about causation.

A relative risk (RR) estimate with a 95% confidence interval provides key information about whether a given intervention is likely to be associated with a given outcome and to what extent. When evaluating an RR estimate and confidence interval, one should ask three key questions:

• Is the RR estimate greater than or less than 1.0?
• Does the confidence interval include 1.0?
• How wide is the confidence interval?

An RR estimate describes the risk of a given outcome in one group compared with the risk in another group. In the scenario described above, the RR equals the risk of recurrence of urinary tract infection (UTI) in the treatment group divided by the risk of recurrence in the placebo group.

• When the treatment group has a lower risk of recurrence than the placebo group (the desired outcome), the RR will be <1.0.
• When the treatment group has a higher risk of recurrence, the RR will be >1.0.
• When the treatment and placebo groups have the same risk of recurrence, the RR will equal 1.0.

In addition to the RR estimate itself, one must also consider the 95% confidence interval for the estimate. The confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. For example, if the RR estimate is 0.78 and the 95% confidence interval is 0.71–0.86, then we can be confident that the true RR value lies somewhere between 0.71 and 0.86, which would indicate a likely protective effect of the intervention. If, however, the confidence interval included 1.0 (for example, 0.75–1.2), then that would suggest that an RR value of 1.0 is plausible - and that there may be no real difference in outcomes between the treatment and placebo groups.

The last piece of information to evaluate when considering an RR estimate is the width of the confidence interval, which provides information about the precision of the estimate. The narrower the confidence interval is, the more precise the RR estimate is. For example, if the RR estimate is 0.74 and the 95% confidence interval is 0.37 to 0.99, that would mean that the intervention likely has a protective effect, but the magnitude of that effect could be anywhere from a 1% relative reduction in risk (which would be negligible) to a 63% relative reduction in risk (which would be substantial). If, however, the RR estimate was 0.78 and the 95% confidence interval was 0.71 to 0.86, that would suggest that the relative reduction in risk is in the range of 14% to 29%.

In this scenario, the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a confidence interval that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest confidence interval) is the RR of 0.78 (confidence interval, 0.71–0.86).

Key learning point: In population statistics, as the width of the confidence interval increases, the precision of a given measurement decreases.

questions.text:
A new experimental test is being studied for the early detection of HIV infection. Using a gold standard method, the investigators identified 500 people with HIV and 500 without HIV. Among the 500 people with HIV, 400 tested positive on the experimental test; among the 500 people without HIV, 450 tested negative on the experimental test.
What is the sensitivity and specificity of the new experimental test?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sensitivity measures how well a test detects disease; specificity measures how well a test detects the absence of disease. Setting up a 2x2 table can be helpful for calculating a test’s sensitivity and specificity. The data and calculations in this case are shown in the table below. Also see “Features of a two-by-two table summarizing screening or diagnostic test results” table. We can calculate the sensitivity and specificity by looking at the two columns in the table:
Sensitivity = 400/(400+100) x 100% = 80%
Specificity = 450/(450+50) x 100% = 90%

The positive and negative predictive values of the test are also of interest and can be calculated using the rows of the table.
• Positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that someone with a positive test actually has disease.
• Negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that someone with a negative test, in fact, does not have disease.

Importantly, these values are highly dependent on the prevalence of disease in the population being tested. In the study population described in this case, the prevalence of HIV infection was 50% because of the study design employed. The data therefore allow us to calculate the PPV and NPV of the test for populations with a prevalence of disease of 50% :
PPV = 400/(400+50) x 100% = 89%
NPV = 450/(450+100) x 100% = 82%

If the prevalence of disease in the tested population was only 1%, the PPV would be only 7.5% and the NPV would be 99.8%. Thus, when interpreting the PPV and NPV of a test, one must ensure that the prevalence of disease in the population from which the values were derived matches the prevalence of disease in the population in whom the test is being used.

Key learning point: Two important characteristics of a clinical test are the proportion of patients without disease who have a negative test (specificity) and the proportion of patients with disease who have a positive test (sensitivity).

B) INCORRECT:

The correct sensitivity and specificity in this case have different values.

C) INCORRECT:

The correct sensitivity and specificity in this case have different values. Assuming a disease prevalence of 50%, the negative predictive value and positive predictive value are 82% and 89%, respectively.

D) INCORRECT:

The correct sensitivity and specificity in this case have different values. Assuming a disease prevalence of 50%, the positive predictive value and negative predictive value are 89% and 82%, respectively.

E) INCORRECT:

The correct specificity in this case has a different value. Assuming a disease prevalence of 50%, the negative predictive value is 82%.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents in the winter with fever, runny nose, cough, and bilateral leg pain for the past 2 days. A point-of-care rapid influenza test, which has a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 98%, is positive for influenza infection.
What additional information would be most helpful in determining the probability that this patient has influenza?

choices.text: The prevalence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community who had an upper respiratory infection during the past month
The incidence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community during the past winter
The proportion of 2-year-old children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive rapid-test result
The lifetime incidence of influenza among all children in the patient’s community
The proportion of 2-year-old children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative rapid-test result

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

All screening and diagnostic tests have two intrinsic test characteristics: sensitivity (the proportion of patients with the condition who test positive) and specificity (the proportion of patients without the condition who test negative). However, a more useful concept for clinicians who are interpreting diagnostic tests are the positive predictive value (PPV), which is the probability that an individual who tests positive actually has the condition, and the negative predictive value (NPV), which is the probability that an individual who tests negative does not have the condition. In this particular scenario, the PPV is the proportion of all 2-year-old children with an upper respiratory infection (URI) and a positive rapid-test result who actually have influenza infection, as determined on a gold-standard test (polymerase-chain-reaction assay or viral culture).

The PPV and NPV depend on both the intrinsic characteristics of the test and the pretest probability that the patient has the condition of interest. The pretest probability is best approximated from the prevalence of the condition in a population similar to that of the patient in question. Therefore, the additional information that would be most helpful in determining whether this patient truly has influenza is the prevalence of influenza among 2-year-old children in his community who had URI symptoms in the past month. Using the same diagnostic test (with a given sensitivity and specificity) in a population with higher disease prevalence increases the PPV; that is, someone who tests positive is more likely to have true disease. Conversely, increased prevalence results in decreased NPV; individuals who test negative are more likely to actually have disease. Therefore, when considering predictive values of diagnostic tests, it is important to take into account the influence of the prevalence of disease.

Key learning point: The pretest probability that a patient has a given condition is best estimated by the prevalence of that condition in a population similar to that of the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Incidence is defined as the rate at which a condition occurs in a population. For example, if influenza diagnoses among children in a particular community accrue at a rate of 3% per person-month during the winter, then the children in that community have a 3% chance each month of being diagnosed with influenza. Incidence does not define the pretest probability for an individual patient at the time a test is administered.

C) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-positive result on the rapid test, but does not help to define a pretest probability.

D) INCORRECT:

The lifetime incidence of influenza in this case would be the proportion of children in the community who were ever diagnosed with influenza, no matter the age at diagnosis. This information would not provide the best pretest probability of influenza for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-negative result on the rapid test, but it does not help to define a pretest probability.

questions.text:
You are asked to present to a local school community about the importance of bicycle helmet use. As part of your literature search beforehand, you identify a prospective cohort study, in which researchers enrolled 150 children who reported cycling at least twice a week and always using a helmet, and 150 children who reported cycling at least twice a week but never using a helmet. The participants were followed for 10 years with an annual survey asking whether they had sustained a head injury while biking in the preceding year. At the end of the study period, researchers reported that the relative risk of head injury while biking in the group of children who never wore helmets was 1.37 (95% confidence interval, 1.13–1.97).
How can we interpret the estimated relative risk from this study?

choices.text: Study participants who never wore helmets were 37 times more likely to experience head injury than those who always wore helmets
There was an average of 1.37 more head injuries per year in study participants who never wore helmets than in those who always wore them
Study participants who never wore helmets had a 37% increase in the risk of head injury compared with those who always wore helmets
37% of study participants who never wore helmets experienced head injury
Study participants who never wore helmets had a 137% increase in the risk of head injury compared with those who always wore helmets

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement is incorrect. A relative risk of 1.37 means children who never wear helmets are 1.37 times more likely to experience head injury than those who always wear helmets.

B) INCORRECT:

This statement is incorrect. There was an average of 1.37 more head injuries per 10-year study period (not in 1 year) in study participants who never wore helmets than in those who always wore them.

C) CORRECT:

Relative risk estimates the relationship between an exposure and an outcome of interest. It is calculated by determining the risk in the exposed group and dividing it by the risk in the unexposed group. The data from this type of study can be shown in a 2 x 2 table: See “Two-by-two table”.

Using the values from the table, we can calculate the risk in each group:
Risk in the exposed group = (number with the event among the exposed) / (total number exposed) = a / (a + b)
Risk in the unexposed group = (number with the event among the unexposed) / (total number unexposed) = c / (c + d)
The relative risk is the ratio of these two risks:
Relative risk = [a / (a + b)] / [c / (c + d)]

A relative risk of 1 means that the event is equally likely to occur in the exposed and unexposed groups. A relative risk >1 means that the event is more likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. A relative risk <1 means the event is less likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group.

In this study, with 150 participants in each group, the 2 x 2 table might look like the one shown below.
The risk of head injury in children not wearing helmets is 26/150 = 0.1733
The risk of head injury in children who wear helmets is 19/150 = 0.1267
The relative risk is 0.1733 / 0.1267 = 1.37

This relative risk can be described in a few different ways:
• The risk of head injury is increased by 37% in those who never wear helmets
• There is a 37% increased risk of head injury in children who never wear helmets compared with those who always do
• Nonuse of helmets is associated with a 37% increase in the risk of head injury
• Children who never wear helmets are 1.37 times more likely to experience head injury than those who always wear helmets
The relative risk does not tell us the percentage of children who never wear helmets who experience head injury (that would be the risk in the exposed; 17% in this study) or the absolute change in risk from lack of helmet use (that would be the risk difference). The risk difference for this case is 0.1733 - 0.1267 = 0.05.

Key learning point: Relative risk is the ratio of the risk of an outcome in an exposed group compared with the risk in an unexposed group.

D) INCORRECT:

The relative risk does not tell us the percentage of children who never wear helmets who experience head injury (that would be the risk in the exposed; 17% in this study).

E) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of 1.37 indicates a 37% increase in risk, not 137%.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician in the winter with fever, runny nose, cough, and bilateral leg pain for the past 2 days. A point-of-care rapid influenza test, which has a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 98%, is positive for influenza infection. Which of the following additional information would be most helpful in determining the probability that this patient has influenza?

choices.text: The proportion of 2-year-old children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive rapid-test result
The lifetime incidence of influenza among all children in the patient’s community
The proportion of 2-year-old children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative rapid-test result
The prevalence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community who had an upper respiratory infection during the past month
The incidence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community during the past winter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-positive result on the rapid test, but does not help to define a pretest probability.

B) INCORRECT:

The lifetime incidence of influenza in this case would be the proportion of children in the community who were ever diagnosed with influenza, no matter the age at diagnosis. This information would not provide the best pretest probability of influenza for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Knowing the proportion of children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-negative result on the rapid test, but it does not help to define a pretest probability.

D) CORRECT:

The pretest probability is best approximated from the prevalence of the condition in a population similar to that of the patient in question. In this particular scenario, the PPV is the proportion of all 2-year-old children with an upper respiratory infection and a positive rapid-test result who actually have influenza infection, as determined on a gold-standard test (polymerase-chain-reaction assay or viral culture). Using the same diagnostic test in a population with higher disease prevalence increases the PPV; that is, someone who tests positive is more likely to have true disease. Conversely, increased prevalence results in decreased NPV; individuals who test negative are more likely to actually have disease. Therefore, when considering predictive values of diagnostic tests, it is important to take into account the influence of the prevalence of disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Incidence is defined as the rate at which a condition occurs in a population. For example, if influenza diagnoses among children in a particular community accrue at a rate of 3% per person-month during the winter, then the children in that community have a 3% chance each month of being diagnosed with influenza. Incidence does not define the pretest probability for an individual patient at the time a test is administered.
questions.hint: All screening and diagnostic tests have intrinsic test characteristics such as sensitivity and specificity. However, a more useful concept for clinicians who are interpreting diagnostic tests are the positive predictive value (PPV) and the negative predictive value (NPV). The PPV and NPV depend on both the intrinsic characteristics of the test and the pretest probability that the patient has the condition of interest.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the office to discuss a positive result on an enzyme immunoassay (EIA) screening test for HIV infection conducted 2 days ago. The results of an expedited confirmatory HIV test are pending. At this time, the patient would like to know the probability that he actually has HIV infection, given the positive EIA result. A review of the characteristics of the EIA test, compared with the gold standard, polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing, shows the following data:



PCR positive
PCR negative


EIA positive
125 = true positive
13 = false positive


EIA negative
1 = false negative
950 = true negative


After this patient’s positive EIA screening test, which of the following most accurately identifies the probability that he actually has HIV infection?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The positive predictive value (PPV) of a screening test is the probability that a patient with a positive result actually has the disease, making the PPV the pertinent test characteristic in this case. The negative predictive value is the probability that the patient does not have the disease when the test is negative. The higher the predictive values of a screening test, the more valuable the test is. For the HIV test conducted in this scenario, the PPV is calculated as follows: 125/(125+13) x 100% = 90.6%.

B) INCORRECT:

Sensitivity is the probability that a patient with the disease will test positive. In this scenario, sensitivity is calculated as follows: 125/(125+1) x 100% = 99.2%.

C) INCORRECT:

The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that the patient does not have the disease when the test is negative. In this scenario, the NPV is calculated as follows:
950/(950+1) x 100% = 99.9%.

D) INCORRECT:

Specificity is the probability that a patient without the disease will test negative. In this scenario, specificity is calculated as follows: 950/(950+13) x 100% = 98.7%.

E) INCORRECT:

The positive likelihood ratio compares the chance that a patient with the disease will test positive to the chance that a patient without the disease will test positive. In this scenario, it is calculated as follows: positive likelihood ratio = sensitivity/(1 - specificity) = (125/(125+1))/(1 - (950/(950+13))) = 73.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with moderately severe asthma comes to the physician for follow-up. Despite adherence to therapy with an inhaled glucocorticoid and long-acting beta-agonist, she continues to have multiple severe exacerbations requiring hospitalization and systemic glucocorticoid use. The physician is considering initiation of a novel biologic therapy; however, when he discusses this with the patient, she mentions a family member who suffered a severe rash with this drug. The drug product monograph notes that severe skin reactions have been reported since the drug was approved, affecting an estimated 1% of patients who receive the drug. The physician reviews the primary phase 3 research study, which demonstrated the drug’s efficacy in severe asthma, and note that the researchers enrolled 100 patients in the active-drug arm and another 100 patients to the placebo arm. Which of the following is the probability that at least one severe rash was observed in this study?

choices.text: The probability of detection cannot be determined because adverse events occur randomly

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 0%.

B) INCORRECT:

While it is true that adverse events occur randomly, the probability of detecting an adverse event can be estimated using statistical methods.

C) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 10%.

D) CORRECT:

The formula for the probability of detecting an adverse event in a clinical trial is: P(at least 1 adverse event) = 1 - (1 - probability of event)number of study participants. The probability of severe skin reactions has been reported to be 0.01 (1%) and the number of study participants in the active-drug arm is 100. Plugging those numbers into the formula, we get: 1 - (1 - 0.01)100 = 1 - 0.99100 = 1 - 0.366 = 0.634. Therefore, if an adverse reaction occurs in 1% of patients, a study that enrolled 100 patients in the active treatment arm would have a 63% probability of detecting the reaction.

As a more general rule, a research team would have to administer a drug to three times as many participants as the frequency of the event to detect that event with 95% confidence. If the adverse event occurred in 1 in 100 people (1%), one would need to give the drug to roughly 300 people for there to be a 95% likelihood of detecting one event. Therefore, many rare adverse events are reported only in postmarketing studies, when large numbers of patients have been exposed to the therapy in question.

E) INCORRECT:

The probability of detecting an adverse event is not 100%.

questions.text: A novel at-home influenza test is being evaluated as a diagnostic tool. Among 520 patients tested, 242 had a positive test result, and 278 had a negative test result. Of the 242 patients with positive results, 228 had influenza confirmed on a gold-standard test. Of the 278 patients with negative results, 266 did not have influenza on gold-standard testing. Which of the following is the positive likelihood ratio of the at-home influenza test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Based on the information provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 0.86.

B) INCORRECT:

The negative likelihood ratio is the ratio of the false negative rate to the true negative rate and is calculated as (1 - sensitivity)/specificity. Based on the information provided in this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95. Given these values, 0.05 represents the negative likelihood ratio ((1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05) rather than the positive likelihood ratio.

C) CORRECT:

Based on the information provided in this scenario, the test characteristics of the at-home influenza test can be calculated as shown in the table below. Given these values, the positive likelihood ratio can be calculated as follows: 0.95/(1–0.95) = 19. A high LR+ (> 10) indicates that the test is excellent at confirming a disease. The negative likelihood ratio compares the probability of a person without the disease of interest testing negative to the probability of a person with the disease testing negative. For this scenario, it can be calculated as follows: LR- = (1 - sensitivity) / specificity = (1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05. A low negative likelihood ratio (< 0.1) indicates that a negative test is good at ruling out the presence of disease. Together, these ratios suggest that the test performs well in accurately detecting the presence of disease.

If the likelihood ratio of a diagnostic test is 1, it has poor clinical utility.

D) INCORRECT:

In this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95, as shown in the table below. The positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 0.95.

E) INCORRECT:

Based on the information provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 33.
questions.hint: The positive likelihood ratio (LR+) is the ratio of the true positive rate to the false positive rate and is calculated as sensitivity/(1 - specificity).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because she is nervous about her regular use of tanning beds after seeing in a news story that they increase the risk of skin cancer. The paper referenced in the news story describes a prospective cohort study conducted among 600 women aged ≥ 30 years: 300 reported regular use of tanning beds and 300 did not. During the 10-year study period, the women completed annual surveys indicating whether they had been diagnosed with skin cancer in the preceding year. At the end of the 10 years, researchers reported that the relative risk of skin cancer associated with tanning-bed use was 1.63 (95% confidence interval, 1.13–2.36). Which of the following conclusions about the relative risk reported in this study is most appropriate?

choices.text: Study participants who used tanning beds had a 63% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
There was an average of 1.63 more skin-cancer diagnoses per year in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not
63% of study participants who used tanning beds developed skin cancer
Study participants who used tanning beds had a 163% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
Study participants who used tanning beds were 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer than those who did not use tanning beds

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The relative risk (RR) of 1.63 reported in this study means that there was a 63% increased risk of skin cancer in tanning-bed users compared with nonusers.

The RR is calculated by dividing the incidence of disease in the exposed group by the incidence of disease in the unexposed group. An RR of 1 means that the event is equally likely to occur in the exposed and unexposed groups. An RR > 1 means that the event is more likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. An RR < 1 means the event is less likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group.

B) INCORRECT:

There was an average of 1.63 more skin cancer diagnoses per 10-year study period (not in one year) in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not.

C) INCORRECT:

The relative risk does not tell us the percentage of tanning-bed users who develop skin cancer (that would be the risk in the exposed; 21% in this study).

D) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of 1.63 does not mean that tanning-bed users had a 163% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

The relative risk of 1.63 does not mean that tanning-bed users are 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has an elevated prostate-specific antigen test suggesting potential malignancy. The urologist orders an additional diagnostic procedure to confirm the presence of disease. Which measure best ensures minimal false-positives in this setting?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High negative predictive value (NPV) indicates a test's ability to exclude disease when the result is negative, reducing false negatives. However, minimizing false positives in confirmatory testing requires high specificity, not high NPV, which is influenced by disease prevalence.

B) CORRECT:

High specificity in a confirmatory test minimizes false-positive results by accurately identifying individuals without the disease. Specificity is the proportion of true negatives correctly identified, ensuring that a positive result strongly indicates the presence of disease. This is crucial in confirming prostate cancer after an elevated prostate-specific antigen test, which may have false positives. High specificity ensures reliable confirmatory results, reducing unnecessary interventions for those without the condition.

Key learning point: A confirmatory test should have high specificity to accurately confirm the presence of a disease and minimize false positives.

C) INCORRECT:

The negative likelihood ratio assesses a test's ability to rule out disease with a negative result. However, minimizing false positives in confirmatory testing requires high specificity, which ensures accurate identification of individuals without the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

High sensitivity detects most individuals with the disease, minimizing false negatives. However, in confirmatory testing, the goal is to minimize false positives, which is better achieved with high specificity. High sensitivity is more suitable for initial screening rather than confirmation.

questions.text: During a study of a new screening test for Condition X, 150 people with the disease and 300 without it were tested. Among those with the disease, 120 tested positive. Among those without disease, 60 tested positive. Which figure best represents this test’s sensitivity?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sensitivity measures a test's ability to correctly identify individuals with the disease. It is calculated as the number of true positives divided by the sum of true positives and false negatives. In this study, 120 out of 150 individuals with Condition X tested positive. Thus, the sensitivity is 120/150, which equals 0.8 or 80%. This indicates that the test correctly identified 80% of those with the disease.

Key learning point: Sensitivity is calculated as the number of true positives divided by the total number of people with the disease, reflecting the test's ability to correctly identify those with the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

The calculation of 33% results from dividing the number of diseased individuals (150) by the total study population (450), representing disease prevalence, not sensitivity. Sensitivity focuses on the subgroup with the disease, calculated as true positives divided by the total number of diseased individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

A sensitivity of 95% might result from incorrectly including data from individuals without the disease or misapplying another metric, such as specificity. Sensitivity should be calculated solely from the diseased group, using true positives over the total number of diseased individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

The value of 67% is derived from the positive predictive value (PPV), calculated as true positives divided by all positive test results (true positives plus false positives). Sensitivity, however, is the proportion of diseased individuals who test positive, calculated as 120/150, or 80%.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes is assessed for retinopathy using a new screening tool. The manufacturer reports a sensitivity of 90%. What does this claim most accurately mean?

choices.text: Ninety percent of all test results from this screening tool are accurate
Ninety percent of patients who do not have retinopathy will test negative
Ninety percent of patients who test positive truly have retinopathy
Ninety percent of patients who have retinopathy will test positive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement confuses sensitivity with overall test accuracy. Sensitivity only measures the correct identification of those with the disease. Overall accuracy considers both true positives and true negatives and depends on sensitivity, specificity, and disease prevalence.

B) INCORRECT:

This statement describes specificity, not sensitivity. Specificity is the proportion of true negatives among those without the disease, calculated as true negatives divided by the sum of true negatives and false positives. Sensitivity measures the ability to identify true positives among those with the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

This statement describes the positive predictive value (PPV), not sensitivity. PPV is the proportion of positive test results that are true positives, calculated as true positives divided by the sum of true positives and false positives. Sensitivity, however, measures the proportion of true positives among those with the disease and does not indicate the accuracy of positive test results.

D) CORRECT:

Sensitivity refers to a test's ability to correctly identify individuals with a disease. It is calculated as the number of true positives divided by the sum of true positives and false negatives. A sensitivity of 90% means that 90% of patients with diabetic retinopathy will be correctly identified by the test, while 10% may receive a false-negative result. High sensitivity is crucial in screening to ensure most cases are detected, minimizing the risk of missing affected individuals.

Key learning point: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease.

questions.text: A new screening test for a rare endocrine disorder is introduced in a large asymptomatic population. Although the test has high specificity (97%) and high sensitivity (95%), many apparently healthy individuals test positive. Which concept best explains why so many positives occur in a low-prevalence setting?

choices.text: Sensitivity declines as disease prevalence decreases
Negative predictive value is reduced when prevalence is low
High test specificity ensures minimal false-positive results
Positive predictive value is reduced in conditions with low disease prevalence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensitivity, the proportion of true positives among those with the disease, is an intrinsic property of a test and remains constant regardless of disease prevalence. In low-prevalence settings, the number of true positives is low, but this does not affect sensitivity. The issue is the low positive predictive value, not a decline in sensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that a negative test result indicates absence of disease. In low-prevalence settings, NPV is high because most individuals are disease-free, resulting in many true negatives. The issue in low-prevalence settings is reduced positive predictive value, not NPV.

C) INCORRECT:

High specificity means few false positives among those without the disease. However, in low-prevalence settings, the large number of healthy individuals can still result in many false positives, reducing the positive predictive value despite high specificity.

D) CORRECT:

Positive predictive value (PPV) indicates the likelihood that a person with a positive test result actually has the disease. In low-prevalence settings, even tests with high sensitivity (95%) and specificity (97%) yield many false positives relative to true positives. The formula for PPV shows that when prevalence is low, the contribution of true positives is small compared to false positives. Thus, in a large asymptomatic population, the number of false positives can be substantial, reducing the PPV and leading to many individuals testing positive without having the disorder.

Key learning point: In a low prevalence population, screening tests are more likely to yield false positive results due to the larger number of true negatives compared to true positives.

questions.text: A newly implemented screening test for an asymptomatic condition detects cases earlier than previous methods. Observers note that the average survival from time of diagnosis appears longer, although the natural disease course seems unchanged. Which phenomenon best explains this apparent increase in survival?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selection bias involves systematic differences in study participants, potentially affecting outcomes. The scenario describes increased time from diagnosis to death due to earlier detection, not differences in participant characteristics. Therefore, selection bias does not explain the observed increase in survival time.

B) CORRECT:

Lead-time bias occurs when a screening test detects a disease earlier in its natural history, artificially extending the time from diagnosis to outcome (e.g., death) without altering the disease's course. This results in an apparent increase in survival time from diagnosis, even though the actual survival from disease onset remains unchanged. For instance, if a screening method identifies a condition months earlier than symptom-based diagnosis, the measured survival time from diagnosis increases without improving prognosis.

Key learning point: Screening programs are most effective in the pre-clinical disease stage, where the disease is present but not yet symptomatic, allowing for early intervention to improve outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

Overdiagnosis bias involves detecting diseases that would not have become clinically significant, increasing incidence without affecting mortality. While it can confound screening outcomes, the scenario describes earlier detection leading to longer apparent survival, not the identification of non-threatening cases, making overdiagnosis bias an incorrect explanation.

D) INCORRECT:

Length-time bias occurs when screening disproportionately detects slower-progressing diseases, leading to an overrepresentation of less aggressive cases in the screened population. This can make survival outcomes appear better due to the indolent nature of these cases. However, the scenario describes earlier detection without a change in disease aggressiveness, making length-time bias an incorrect explanation.

questions.text: An outpatient clinic introduces a new screening test for a relatively rare autoimmune disorder.
